PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
The Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage List.

Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of The Reef, only 14 per cent of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef Region has been declared marine park.
The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef waters is to prohibit oil drilling in the Region and its vicinity.
This can only be effected by declaring the whole area of the Region a marine park under the above legislation.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to take action to hold a referendum together with the next Federal Elections on the question that:

The entire area of the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounding waters, defined as the Great Barrier Reef Region in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, as amended 1978, be immediately declared a marine park under the provisions of that Act.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Private Enterprise Employees: Retirement Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth our concern that:
1. The Income Tax Assessment Act (the Act) and its administration is inadequate in providing retirement benefits for employees in private enterprise;
2. The Commissioner of Taxation (Commissioner) denies deductions necessary to index retirement pensions;
3. Deductions for the self-employed and employed are inadequate;
4. The Commissioner has exercised his discretion improperly by negating a choice the Act allows on investment in Government Securities;
5. The Commissioner's constant alterations to guidelines and lack of communication has created great uncertainty;
6. The Commissioner is acting arbitrarily, and without proper notice in restricting trustee's investments with employers;
7. The Commissioner seeks to apply new actuarial guidelines retrospectively to July 1981.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, take action to remedy these inadequacies and in particular we pray that action be taken:
(i) To ensure that the Commissioner exercises his discretion only with proper regard to legal principles;
(ii) To ensure that the Commissioner does not delegate to auditors part of his function of administering the Act;
(iii) To enact legislation allowing proper levels of retirement benefit to be provided;

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects, namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over the seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS AND TAXATION REBATES: DE FACTO SPOUSES

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware of an anomaly between social security provisions and income tax provisions as they relate to de facto marriages, namely, that if a woman is living in a de facto relationship with a man his income is taken into account when she applies for unemployment benefit but because they are not married they are disqualified from consideration for the dependent spouse rebate? Can he give a rationale for this? Will the Government give urgent attention to making the situation consistent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the different treatment which is afforded to the de facto spouse under social security law and taxation law. Indeed, it is a matter which has been the subject of informal discussion between the Treasurer and me. In general it can be said that under the social security law a person is treated in the same way, whether married or living in a de facto relationship akin to marriage. That is sometimes to the advantage of the de facto spouse and sometimes to his or her disadvantage. For example, in the unemployment benefit situation, which was mentioned by Senator Martin, it is an advantage in the sense that, if a man or a woman seeks unemployment benefit and is able to demonstrate that he or she has a dependent spouse, an additional payment can be made for that dependent spouse as part of the unemployment benefit. It can, however, operate as a disqualifying factor. Mention was made of this recently in the Senate. A person in a de facto situation who is receiving or who has claimed a supporting parent's benefit may be disqualified from having the benefit because he or she is not a supporting parent living alone and having the care and maintenance of children. Under the taxation law the dependent spouse allowance, as I recall it, is available only to a person who is a de jure spouse -in other words, a person who is legally married to the person claiming the deduction. So there is a difference.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Martin asked whether that difference ought to be removed. I think it is important that there should be no change in the social security provision because clearly, in a system where the concern is the maintenance at some minimum income level of people who are without other income, it is important to take into account very carefully the actual situation of the people concerned. I do not think Senator Martin would support, and certainly I would not support, any removal of the benefits which flow to a de facto spouse. On the other hand, I think different considerations arise under tax law where one might say that the additional privileges which are afforded might properly be given to those who undertake the legal responsibilities of marriage. But basically I suppose that part of the question relates to the responsibilities of my colleague the Treasurer. I will refer Senator Martin's concern, as expressed by this question, to him. He may think it is necessary to expand on the reply which I have given.

I refer the Minister to an advertisement in the West Australian newspaper of 11 September, wherein the West Australian Trades and Labour Council warned tenderers for work on the Yeelirrie uranium project that the uranium policy of the Australian Council of Trade Unions banning the mining and export of Australia's uranium will be enforced during construction. Is this not a direct challenge from the trade union movement to Western Mining Corporation and its partners that development at Yeelirrie will be sabotaged by industrial action? Is it not a crude attempt to warn off potential contractors at Yeelirrie with threats of industrial action to enforce a trade union policy which is blatantly political?

QUESTION.PARA: Given that the project stage alone will employ 650 people and create a town of 1,500 people, bringing with it further employment in service industries as well as in the provision of infrastructure in the form of roads, water, power and communications, and given the Australian Labor Party's policy of opposition to uranium mining, is this not but another example of the sort of industrial disruption which is damaging Australia's wealth and prosperity and denying a job to those in need of employment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important question. I have seen the advertisement in the West Australian in which, as Senator Crichton-Browne says, the Trades and Labour Council and affiliated unions have advised companies tendering for work in the Western Mining Corporation's Yeelirrie project that the ACTU uranium policy banning the mining and export of Australia's uranium ' will be enforced during construction'-they are their words. This raises a very serious question inside the kind of society that is Australia. Inside Australia, at both the Federal and State government levels, the mining, milling and export of uranium is a legal operation; it has been so and remains so. For any people to say that they will take action to prevent what is a totally legal situation is a lawless attempt and must be condemned very strongly indeed. It must be condemned for many reasons. We have had examples of lawlessness in trade unions in recent times. This is another attempt at lawlessness on their part.

ANSWER.PARA: It is clear that the Western Mining Corporation is undertaking a legal operation. It is clear that that operation is in every way safe and appropriate within the laws and the health conditions of the land. It is clear-I repeat this -that the International Atomic Energy Agency has said and has repeated continuously that the living standards of the countries of the world will not be able to be sustained, no matter what other alternative energy sources there are, unless there is a very significant increase in the use of uranium for nuclear power generation. So those who are attempting to stop the flow of uranium from Australia for nuclear power purposes are in fact frustrating the maintenance of living standards, frustrating both the social and economic welfare of people overseas.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Let the Labor Party protest as it may. I repeat that the body that has perhaps the most authoritative overview of the energy requirements of this world of ours has said that if the living conditions of the ordinary people of this world are to be maintained, more and more nuclear power stations must be established and more and more uranium must flow from countries such as Australia. If there are unions which, by lawless action, are seeking to deny this, they are not simply robbing Australia; they are robbing the people of the world of their living standards.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne is utterly right. Here in Australia the mining and milling of uranium has been established, under the Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry, to be a perfectly safe process and one that is absolutely normal. Throughout the world there are some 250 or more nuclear power stations which have functioned for over 20 years. The safety record of those stations is better than that of alternative power stations. There are more than 250 nuclear power stations under construction at this moment and another 250 on the drawing boards. Australia is one of the key sources for uranium in the world. It is against this background that this kind of lawlessness is being foreshadowed. It is a tragedy that it occurs at a time when Australia needs to create useful jobs for its people. Our record in job creation is better than that of the free world around us. Nevertheless, with the opposition of the unions and the Australian Labor Party, which party is opposed to uranium mining, we face a denial of jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everybody. The electorate-everybody.

—The Leader of the Opposition has suggested that the electorate is opposed to it. Gallup polls indicate that a significant majority of Australians are not opposed to the mining, milling and export of uranium. A State government is giving the legal authority for a mining company to operate, the Federal Government is giving the legal authority for the export of the uranium, and a trade union is advertising a threat and a duress. To the world outside this can mean only one thing: As Senator Crichton-Browne has said, it means that the trade union movement in Australia has the capacity to stand over corporations in Australia and prevent them from carrying out their normal contracts. This is the kind of lawlessness that will destroy jobs in Australia. It must be condemned totally.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. It is stated in the Budget Papers that $5m has been allocated for high priority new child care projects. Does the Minister realise that there are thousands of Australian families in desperate need of child care which do not receive any because the Government has not allocated any new funds since 1980 to extend child care projects? Can the Minister make this $5m available without requiring the introduction of amending legislation? If so, when will the funds be made available? If not, will he introduce the necessary legislation in this parliamentary session?

—I am pleased to say that there is no need for amending legislation before new child care projects can be approved. Over the past week I have been considering the first list of recommendations which have been put forward by my Department on high priority new applications. I hope to be in a position to announce approval for some of those within the next few days. That is subject to normal administrative processing at this stage. I expect the balance of funds to be allocated over the coming months. My Department is working on putting before me a series of recommendations following inquiry of those organisations which had outstanding applications and which were advised last year that there would be no approvals or new projects during the last financial year. That process is well in hand. As I said, I expect the first announcements to be made sometime during this week or, at worst, over the weekend. That will enable the very early expansion of a number of child care places in a number of high priority areas.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. With reference to the drought relief measures recently announced by the Commonwealth Government, I ask the Minister whether he is aware that the township of Mount Morgan west of Rockhampton is out of water and is being forced to bring it in by rail at a cost of $1,200 a day on week days and $2,000 a day at the weekend. Bearing in mind that mining ceased at Mount Morgan some years ago and that the small resident population includes a high proportion of age pensioners, I ask whether, under the measures introduced by the Commonwealth, Mount Morgan would qualify for support in relation to water cartage.

—That is a point which I will need to check. But my understanding is that the water cartage provisions announced a couple of weeks ago by the Minister for Primary Industry are directed to the needs of primary producers- to their water needs, fodder needs, need for carry-on finance and so on. I did hear a radio report with respect to the town water supply at Mount Morgan which indicated that water is being carted to that town at very considerable cost. I would have thought that that would come within the normal relief measures which are already the subject of agreement between the Commonwealth and the States and which involve some cost sharing. I need to check the precise application of those rules to the Mount Morgan situation. As I understand it, it is a matter directly concerning the viability of the town water supply during a period of extended drought. It is a little outside what is normally thought of as a drought relief measure, but clearly it is a very great problem for those people. I will check the matter with both the Minister for Primary Industry and the Prime Minister, who would probably be the responsible Minister, and let the honourable senator have an early reply.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, and it refers to reports last week of a study headed by Dr Trevor Beard of the Department of Health which indicates that four out of five cases of high blood pressure in Australia can be treated effectively solely through the use of a salt-free diet. I am sure the Minister will agree that that is many more than was previously supposed. Is the Minister aware that the National Heart Foundation has claimed that 20 per cent of Australians are being treated or should be treated for hypertension? Since this indicates that a dangerous health condition in almost two and a half million people could be relieved simply by a substantial reduction in salt intake, will the Government now urgently consider, in consultation with the States, legislation to compel all manufacturers of processed foods to state the salt content clearly on their product labels? Is the Minister aware that many, if not all, brands of prepared baby foods contain unspecified amounts of salt? Will the Government also institute a study into the possibility that this may be unnecessarily perverting the taste of Australian children and predisposing them towards an unhealthy and, eventually, even fatal dietary habit?

—I am not aware of the report to which Senator Mason refers but I am well aware of the medical conditions and the medical factors which form the substance of his question. The importance to health of a salt-free diet, a low salt diet or a reasonable salt diet is well known. Indeed, many cases of high blood pressure can be treated, if not by salt-free diet, certainly by simple medication that removes salt from the body. There is no argument about that. But the question really goes to other matters. It goes to whether manufacturers of certain foodstuffs should be compelled to have salt contents shown on the label. This is properly a matter for my colleague, the Minister for Health. I am sure he would want advice from the National Health and Medical Research Council which has matters like this under consideration. I understand it has been doing some work on the subject of labelling and has had some consultation on nutrition matters with industry, governments and medical authorities. I know they would want to consider the points raised by the honourable senator and I undertake to have a reference made on his behalf.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. With the continual loss of jobs in Australia due largely to cheaper imports of steel, timber and manufactured goods, will the Minister tell the Senate which areas of employment the Government will preserve? Are Australian workers to be considered only in wartime and disregarded in peacetime? What immediate and long term plans does the Government have to save local industries before many are past recovery? Is it not time that this Federal Government showed some pro-Australian initiatives and listened to commonsense proposals of ordinary people instead of following the advice of the so-called economic and financial experts, many of whom could not organise a peanut stall at a school fete, let alone the affairs of a nation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised at the question because I have heard from Labor spokesmen statements that indeed protection in Australia was too high and that there should be a reduction in protection. I felt that those statements were ill-considered at times when jobs need to be protected.
—They are all right overseas, but back here it is different.

—I take it that the Australian Labor Party is saying that there should not be as much protection. It is very hard to know. In recent times the Government has indicated that it intends to maintain the level of protection.
—Here, but not overseas.

—The fact of the matter is that in Australia we have a good record in that regard. We have two very great difficulties with regard to our being able to compete and create jobs. Of course the recession outside is having an overwhelming effect. The fact of the matter is that the level of unemployment in free world countries is running at about double what it is in Australia.
—That is utter rubbish. Only in the United Kingdom is that true.

—At this moment in western Europe almost 30 million people are unemployed. Those figures can be obtained and shown. The lowering of demand throughout the free world, of course, has had an effect upon Australia's trade. We, unlike the Labor Party, are determined to maintain protection. We have established protection policies for the automotive industry. We have agreed to freeze steel imports. The Labor Party has expressed through its spokesmen that it would lower the level of protection. I take it that that is Labor Party policy; it has not been refuted.

ANSWER.PARA: If we want to maintain and expand employment in Australia we have to look at the real world outside. There is now wage restraint in the countries with which we trade. Those countries are now getting their inflation rate down, primarily by wage restraint. If Australia wants to trade overseas we must be reliable traders and we must reduce our industrial disruption. We have maintained protection policies. We have made our determination to do that perfectly clear, as distinct from the policy of the Labor Party. We have indicated a policy of wage restraint and we are pursuing that. We are talking to the trade union movement and to employers about the need for industrial peace and co-operation. If we want jobs, if we want to compete, that is the road to it. In fact that is the road that the people overseas are taking now and they are the people with whom we have to compete.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Will the Minister seriously do something about preserving the jobs of the timber workers in South Australia? Some 2,000 people are in fear of losing their jobs simply because of the importation--

—Order! That is an entirely different question and not related in any way to the first question asked. I suggest to all honourable senators that when they take advantage of asking supplementary questions they make sure that the questions are supplementary questions.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Education and refer him to reports that the Government has directed that 15 per cent of tertiary and further education particular purpose funding be diverted into advanced English programs for migrants which were originally the responsibility of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I ask the Minister for confirmation of this direction and for advice as to how the TAFE organisations are to give effect to the decision. What liaison between the two departments will be forthcoming?

—It is correct that the Government recently considered a report from the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs and that one of the recommendations accepted by the Government was that arrangements should be varied in the way set out in Senator Kilgariff's question. What has happened is that the Government has now asked the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to report by the end of October on the ways by which that decision might be implemented. The answer to Senator Kilgariff's question, of course, will have to await that report from the TEC. I might add that the Tertiary Education Commission, in its turn, has quite properly referred the matter to the Technical and Further Education Council for its views. I might mention that to date no State Minister for Education has approached me about the Government's decision. I am hopeful that the report from the TEC, when it comes to hand, will in fact contain recommendations for positive action and that these will enable us to put into effect the Government's decision in a way that helps advance TAFE arrangements in Australia generally.

—I ask the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer whether she has yet been able to obtain any information about the $ 400m that disappeared from the Treasury, rested overnight and was spent the next day.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was the subject of an earlier question from Senator Keeffe--
—Two questions.

—Subsequent to the reminder question, I incorporated a response in Hansard. I think that would have been about a week ago; I will have it looked up. The explanation that was called for in the honourable senator's question is in Hansard.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether the Treasurer wrote to the Minister for Primary Industry on 16 February 1982 in these terms:

QUESTION.PARA: I have had for some time now a growing concern about the scope there is for tax minimisation as a result of the interaction of the I.E.D. scheme and the income averaging provisions of the income tax law.

Why has the Treasurer not taken action to end what he himself recognised as a tax rort at least as early as last February? Is it because the National Country Party mafia is standing over him or, following his own precedent, is the Treasurer waiting until the public becomes so angry that the public frightens him more than the National Country Party already does?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, is it not interesting that when one uses words against the Australian Labor Party in this House it is naughty; but to call the National Country Party a Mafia is no sin at all? This is an interesting situation because when I have made, on my feet, a collective reference to the Labor Party members of that party have stood up one by one and said that they were being defamed. Let me simply say at the outset that I reject totally any such offensive words about the National Country Party. The National Country Party is a party elected by the people of Australia. To call the National Country Party a Mafia is a thorough insult to the electors. I hope that the electors who vote for the National Country Party know that the Labor Party considers that that is their judgment. I think it is very important that the people of the rural districts should know that they are being regarded as part of a mafia. So let us have that clear and let us have no more argument in this place about collective words in this situation.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know whether the Treasurer wrote to the Minister for Primary Industry on 16 February in those terms at all. I suggest that Senator Walsh give me a copy of the letter. I will then take it up with the Treasurer and ask him to respond.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Now that the histrionics are finished, will the Minister answer the question? Will he tell the Senate whether a letter was written in such terms and why the Treasurer, who purports to be conducting a continuing campaign against tax evasion, continues to tolerate what he himself has identified as a tax minimisation practice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Had Senator Walsh been listening and not shouting, as is his wont, he would have known that I said that if he would give me a copy of that letter I would take it to the Treasurer and ask the Treasurer to identify it, if it is authentic, and to give a response to the rest of the question. I look forward to getting a copy of the letter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TAX AVOIDANCE: APPOINTMENT OF SPECIAL PROSECUTOR

Specifically, have barristers considered been rejected after scrutiny by the Australian Taxation Office? What are the reasons for some barristers being found unacceptable? When will the Government be announcing the appointment of the special prosecutor?

—Honourable senators will recall that the Senate has just completed dealing with legislation which permits the Government to appoint a special prosecutor or special prosecutors for particular purposes. It is the announced intention of the Government to appoint a special prosecutor to deal with matters which have been the subject of very considerable debate in this place in recent times. I will refer the detail of the question to my colleague Mr Brown, the Acting Attorney-General, but it is my understanding that an announcement in this matter will be made very soon.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. What assurance can we have that recovering gold through the use of cyanide-based chemicals as proposed by Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd will not result in pollution of the surrounding countryside and in particular underground water supplies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw an article on this matter either today or yesterday in the Australian or one of the other newspapers. I have asked my Department to give me information concerning the use of the cyanide process elsewhere and whether or not there are stringent rules regarding health. As soon as I get that response, which I sought today, I will let Senator Watson know.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an advertisement in today's Australian Financial Review headed 'How you can fight a bottom-of-the- harbour claim'? The advertisement states:

QUESTION.PARA: A complete four-cassette recording of my recent seminar is now available . . . Other topics: TAX AVOIDANCE IS ALIVE AND WELL IN AUSTRALIA . . . RECENT COURTROOM VICTORIES . . . SIX BRAND NEW FISCAL-FIEND-PROOF TAX AVOIDANCE SCHEMES . . . HOW TO PROTECT YOUR ASSETS FROM SEIZURE . . . GUIDELINES FOR THE FUTURE.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer the question to the Acting Attorney-General. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH WEST TASMANIA: WORLD HERITAGE LIST

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is it not a fact that the area of Tasmania nominated for listing in the World Heritage List constitutes about 10 per cent of the area of that State and not the quarter claimed by the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Gray?

—The figure which I had been given was 22 per cent or so. That is the figure which I had understood was correct. If one looks at the map one can see that it is obviously a very large area. Whether the correct figure is one percentage or another is something I can only check by reference to the Minister whom I represent, and I will undertake to do that. But I must say that the higher figure is the one I have been using. If it is incorrect I will certainly let Senator Button know.

—I address a question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Did Australia's percentage share of natural gas and coal markets rise in 1981-82 to compensate for the fall in oil consumption?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been quite significant discoveries of natural gas in Australia in recent years. Indeed, I can say in modest terms there have been significant discoveries of oil. In order that honourable senators may understand the situation, I point out that a year or two ago in this place I reported that, although we were 67 per cent self-sufficient in indigenous oil and that figure was likely to fall to 50 per cent by 1985, 40 per cent by 1990 and perhaps 20 per cent by the end of the century, the fall was in fact levelling out. Whilst we are not in the position to be so optimistic at the moment let me simply say that it is possible, if the modest supplies of oil that we are now finding continue, that we will be able to maintain the plateau over this decade. That will be a very exciting thing because it will buy us lead time . But equally it is true that the increase in the use of natural gas-I think this is fundamental to Senator Watson's question-has enabled us to switch from oil to natural gas. This has been most valuable indeed and has led, as published figures show, to a decline in the use of oil.

—My question is ad- dressed to Senator Messner, as the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation or as the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Is it usual for State police to be employed at capital city airports in Australia? What is the role of the many Queensland State police officers who are now working at the Brisbane Airport?
—That is a matter I will need to refer to the Minister for Administrative Services. I undertake to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation. I claim to have been misrepresented in a statement issued by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Wilson) yesterday headed 'Minister Accuses Labor of provoking unrest over Games'. In that statement the Minister made a number of accusations about me and about the Australian Labor Party which are untrue. I will quote briefly from the Minister's statement so that the Senate will understand what I am correcting. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Ian Wilson, today accused the Australian Labor Party of provoking unrest and tension in the period leading up to the Commonwealth Games . . . Mr Wilson said the sort of exaggerated and deliberately provocative political jibes that had been used by the Labor Party on this issue went right against the current attempt by all parties, including Aboriginals themselves, to approach the period of the Commonwealth Games in a spirit of commonsense and moderation. Mr Wilson said that if the Labor Party was going to indulge in that sort of deliberate and unhelpful sensationalism, it would have to examine its own conscience if there were any confrontation at the Games.

At the outset I want to say that I, as the spokesperson for the Australian Labor Party on Aboriginal affairs, have not at any stage said or done anything that could be regarded as provocative about what will happen at the Commonwealth Games in Brisbane. I am concerned that the Minister has made such a misleading statement about my words and actions. I am further concerned and alarmed that this statement by Minister Wilson seems to be the beginning of what probably will be a concerted attempt by the Government to make the Australian Labor Party the scapegoat for any unfortunate episodes that occur. It is quite clear that the actions of the Bjelke-Petersen Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator is now going a bit beyond a personal explanation. She may carry on if she confines her remarks to how she was misrepresented.

—By way of personal explanation I simply say: My role and the role of the Federal Australian Labor Party with regard to the land situation in Queensland have been constructive from the outset. It is more than 18 months now , I think, since the Premier of Queensland announced that he was going to degazette the reserves.
—Order! Senator Ryan, you are speaking wide of the point again. I will hear Senator Sir John Carrick on a point of order.

—I do not mean to interrupt Senator Ryan but my point of order is that this would be an ideal matter for her to raise during the adjournment debate if she wants to make a lengthy speech by way of explanation. I think she is going beyond giving a personal explanation.

—I brought it to the honourable senator's attention that she was digressing very broadly from the point. I think that she may be aware that she was doing so. I suggest she must be close to finishing her personal explanation.

—I am at something of a loss to know how I can explain that both my actions and those of the Labor Party in this matter have been constructive and consultative and have all the time sought a legal and peaceful solution when the claims by the Minister have been so outrageous.
—You just said it.

—All right; I see that this matter is embarrassing the Government, as well it might, because it has been its own irresponsibility and negligence in this matter which have led to the situation which has now arisen. I simply say that it is on record both in this place, particularly in the debate on my private members Bill for Aboriginal land rights in Queensland, and in the many public statements I have issued, that the Australian Labor Party has in the first instance constantly sought a parliamentary legal solution to the land rights question in Queensland and secondly, in every meeting briefing with Aboriginal groups in Queensland has stressed the need for peaceful actions during the Commonwealth Games.

—I was asked a question by Senator MacGibbon during Question Time about possible assistance for the town of Mount Morgan for the expenses incurred in carting water for the town water supply. Inquiries made during Question Time of the Department of Primary Industry have confirmed that under the normal natural disaster relief measures a town may receive a 75 per cent concession on the transport cost for hauling water. I should mention that the assistance is subject to contribution by the Commonwealth after a certain base amount has been spent by the particular State. The base amount varies from State to State and with respect to Queensland it is $4m. So it may be that there is assistance available for Mount Morgan and that the matter should be made the subject of more detailed inquiry.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH WEST TASMANIA: WORLD HERITAGE LIST

TALK.START.PARA: —A few moments ago Senator Button asked me a question without notice concerning South West Tasmania. I now discover that I do have some material in my brief which enables me to give him an answer. The question concerned the percentage of the area of Tasmania which has been nominated for the World Heritage List. I am advised that the whole of the South West has been declared a conservation area under Tasmanian legislation and that that area amounts to 19.8 per cent of the total area of Tasmania. But only part of the area declared a conservation area has been nominated for the World Heritage List. The Australian nomination is entitled 'Western Tasmania Wilderness National Parks' and it consists of the South West National Park, the Franklin Rivers-Lower Gordon Wild Rivers National Park and the Cradle Mountain and Lake St Clair national parks. It is emphasised that the nominated area consisted at the time of national parks already proclaimed under Tasmanian legislation. That area was already protected by State laws and it actually constitutes 11.3 per cent of the total area of Tasmania. Those figures are as precise as we can give to Senator Button.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BUNBURY: PAYMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week Senator Coleman raised a question about the Bunbury regional office of the Department of Social Security and social security payments to wives of construction workers currently on strike at the Worsley project. I reassured Senator Coleman and the Senate of the eligibility of the sorts of people she had mentioned in the question. I have since made inquiries and I am advised by the regional manager in Bunbury that 57 employees of Raymond Engineers Aust. Pty Ltd who are members of the Builders Labourers Federation went on strike on 17 August 1982. As a consequence of the strike 30 or 40 other tradesmen were stood down and on 30 August 1982 the company terminated the employment of the strikers.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that the Bunbury office is currently paying a special benefit to about 10 wives of the people concerned and the unemployment benefit to one wife . The special benefit was paid because the 10 people concerned were described as not having satisfied the work test, which I assume means they were not seeking or were not available for work. The one who was on unemployment benefit was rejected for special benefit as hardship could not be proven. She had money in a bank account. I am advised that the advice alleged to have been given to wives of construction workers at the Worsley project did not come from this Department's Bunbury office. Until the question without notice was asked in Parliament the office had no reason to believe that all those affected were not fully aware of the benefits that may be available from the Department of Social Security.

To ensure that no misunderstanding or ignorance of the possible social security entitlements is occurring, the regional manager has now contacted the staff welfare officer at Raymond Engineers to acquaint him with the fact that assistance may be available to the wives of strikers. If the women are in any doubt they will be told to contact the Bunbury regional office direct. All staff at the office are aware of the availability of benefits to wives of strikers and of the current provisions relating to the payment of unemployment benefit to persons who have been stood down or dismissed because of their participation in a strike. I simply assure the Senate that, notwithstanding the Government's introduction of legislation to vary the law in this area, it would of course be my wish, the wish of the Government and, I am sure, the firm intention of my Department to administer these benefits in accordance with the law as it stands.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Watson asked a question concerning international subscriber dialling information in telephone directories. I have been provided with some information on this matter. Telecom Australia has advised that as ISD becomes a more commonly available service in Australia appropriate detailed information on using the service, additional to that contained in current telephone directories, will be provided. Telecom has advised that it can be difficult to make exact time comparisons by the use of international clocks simply because of the number of different time zones involved and the introduction of summer time within Australia and some other countries.

ANSWER.PARA: However, the honourable senator may be aware that in 1982-83 all metropolitan directories, and some directories of larger provincial centres will contain first a colour information page which has detailed information on ISD calling, including charges in the rest of the world and, secondly, an inclusion on that page referring customers to a separate section of the directory which lists dialling codes for all countries. An indication will also be provided of the time differences between Australia and other countries, but in terms of summer time that may not be complete. This information is available now in brochure form from Telecom business offices.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday Senator Harradine asked me a question in connection with the policy on Australian National Line agency arrangements in Tasmania. ANL has sought the approval of the Minister for Transport to enter into a joint arrangement with Webster Ltd to conduct the agency and shipping activities of both organisations in Tasmania. Webster Ltd is currently the agent for ANL in Hobart and in Bell Bay. ANL conducts its own agency arrangements at Devonport and employs a different agent for this work at Burnie .
