DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN DAIRY CORPORATION AND ASIA DAIRY INDUSTRIES (HONG KONG) LTD

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In light of the fact that this statement has already been made in the other place, I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Mr President, on 12 November 1981 my colleague Senator Carrick tabled documents concerning the audit inspection of the accounts and records of Asia Dairy Industries (H.K.) Limited (ADI) and the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations on the Australian Dairy Corporation (ADC) and its Asian subsidiaries.

The purpose of this statement is to report to the Senate on matters that the Minister for Primary Industry foreshadowed in a statement to the House of Representatives on 29 October 1981 would be the subject of further action or inquiry. These matters are:
Rebate arrangements which applied to Australian Dairy Produce Board and ADC sales of skim milk powder to Holland Milk Products Inc. (HOMPI) during the period 1974 to 1977.
The ownership, future use and control of the Dairying Industry Stabilisation Fund.

General issues of principle relating to statutory authorities raised by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in its report on the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Asian subsidiaries.
The question of whether any breach of the GATT skim milk powder minimum pricing arrangements had occurred apart from those made under the HOMPI arrangement.
HOMPI Rebate Arrangements
On the first of these matters, a brief statement of the background may be of assistance to Honourable Senators.

HOMPI is a company incorporated in the Philippines and engaged there in the manufacture and sale of milk and milk products. The ADC holds 13 1/3% of the share capital. Other shareholders are Holland Canned Milk International, a Dutch dairy manufacturing co-operative, owning 26 2/3%, and G.F. Equity Incorporated, an investment and management company incorporated in the Philippines owning 60%. The principal shareholders in G.F. Equity Inc. are Messrs. W. Uytengsu and G. Young who are also President and Vice-President of HOMPI respectively.
During the period in question-December 1974 to December 1977-the Australian Dairy Produce Board and, from 1975, its successor the ADC, were major suppliers of skim milk powder to HOMPI.

In its report on the ADC and its Asian subsidiaries, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations drew attention to a $25 per tonne rebate on some ADC shipments of skim milk powder to HOMPI that was not paid to HOMPI but to a bank account in Singapore. Honourable Senators will recall that the Minister for Primary Industry said that he wanted to obtain further information on this matter and find out whether the ADC's involvement was appropriate.

To this end the Minister for Primary Industry requested the Auditor-General to undertake an examination of all aspects of the rebate arrangement, including the accounting procedures by which the money was transferred from Australia; the amount and nature of funds remitted overseas by the ADC to be paid into a Singapore account; the agreement by which the original equity in this account was disposed of; and the ultimate disbursement from and closure of the account. He submitted this request to the Auditor-General in a letter dated 10 November 1981 and I now table that letter.

The Auditor-General reported on 27 April 1982, and subsequently on 11 August 1982 he advised of a typographical error in the report. I hereby table both his report and his letter of 11 August 1982. As the Auditor-General's Report was critical of some past actions by the ADC, the Corporation was given the opportunity to respond. Its reply is contained in a document dated 12 July 1982, and I now table this paper. The Auditor-General has been given the opportunity to comment on the ADC response, but his office has replied that it does not believe its role properly extends to any follow up action within the Executive Government that might flow from the Auditor-General's Report. I table this letter, dated 10 August 1982.

The Auditor-General's Report was also referred to the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor for advice and I will have more to say on this aspect later. In the meantime, I table the Crown Solicitor's letter, dated 22 June 1982.
In brief, Mr President, the audit examination indicates that:

In December 1974 the Australian Dairy Produce Board and Asia Dairy Industries contracted to supply HOMPI with not less than 12,000 tons annually of skim milk powder at competitive prices, this contract to remain in force from year to year unless terminated by mutual agreement of the parties.

the Australian Dairy Produce Board (and the ADC when it succeeded the Board) invoiced HOMPI at a rate per tonne that did not allow for various rebates, commissions and other adjustments to which HOMPI was entitled. Such adjustments were effected by the raising of credit notes.

on shipments of skim milk powder during the period to September 1976 credit notes were issued totalling $3,079,145. This total included credits of $1,840, 223 in respect of approved price reductions, $689,516 in respect of a $25 per tonne volume purchase rebate, and $183,148 in respect of a 2% commission.

HOMPI remitted invoiced amounts in full, and these remittances were credited to the skim milk powder reimbursement account at the Reserve Bank of Australia, Melbourne. Funds equivalent to the credit notes were thus accumulated in this account.

such funds were transferred, from time to time, on the instruction of ADC staff , to the Chartered Bank, Singapore, for the account of 'The Chartered Bank, Hong Kong Per instruction of Mr Wilfred Uytengsu or Mr George Young'. Mr Uytengsu, it will be recalled, is President of HOMPI, Mr Young is Vice-President. Interest totalling some $54,883 that had accrued in respect of credit note entitlements was paid to HOMPI, Manila, not to the Singapore account.

The original intention of Mr Uytengsu concerning equity in the funds transferred to the Singapore account is unclear. But given the arrangements among the parties, the Auditor-General considered that the funds belonged to HOMPI which, I repeat, is a Philippines company. There is no evidence, however, that they were at any time reflected in the financial statements of HOMPI.

On 15 November 1976 it was agreed between HOMPI and the ADC that the volume purchase rebate of $25 per tonne be continued on ADC sales of skim milk powder to HOMPI but 'made ex financial account in Singapore and not to exceed the total held in that account to the credit of the Australian Dairy Corporation'. The Auditor-General has reported that the ADC share of the funds in the Singapore Account would have been fully utilised under this arrangement with a shipment of skim milk powder on 3 December 1977.

So far as actual disposition of the funds in the Singapore bank account is concerned, according to documentation produced by Mr Uytgengsu, the entitlement of Holland Canned Milk International arising from its shareholding in HOMPI was required to be paid to a bank account in Switzerland. The Auditor-General was not able to ascertain from Mr Uytengsu the name of the holder of the Swiss account. Apart from the amount stated to have been paid to the Swiss account for Holland Canned Milk International and an amount said by Mr Uytengsu to have been distributed as an incentive bonus to employees, the balance of the funds in the Singapore account appears to have been paid to, or retained by, G. F. Equity Inc . G. F. Equity, it will be recalled, is the third and major shareholder in HOMPI , and has as its principal shareholders Messrs Uytengsu and Young.

According to the Auditor-General's report Mr Uytengsu had indicated that the Singapore bank account was closed on 16 March 1979 after payments were made to Holland Canned Milk International and G. F. Equity. It is also reported by the Auditor-General that he was unable to obtain evidence of payments made to either company or of the closure of the account.

This last aspect was one of those on which the Minister for Primary Industry had asked the Auditor-General to report. But, in light of the fact that the ADC equity in this account had been exhausted in 1977, the closure of the account is not now seen as a matter of direct concern to the Australian Government.

The Auditor-General's Report provides further evidence to that given in his earlier report on the audit inspection on the accounts and records of Asia Dairy Industries (H.K.) Limited (ADI), of improper or inadequate management and accounting arrangements that existed within the ADC and ADI during the 1976 and 1977 period. In this regard Honourable Members will recall that, following receipt of the earlier report of the Auditor-General, the ADC established a special management committee to examine and report on managerial and accounting practices.

Following receipt of the ADC Management Committee Report the Minister for Primary Industry concluded that action was immediately required to overcome certain deficiencies in the management and financial control of ADC. In his statement of 29 October last year, the Minister for Primary Industry reported to the Parliament in the action that has been taken in this regard.

The information available from the latest Auditor-General's report also lends weight to the conclusion that in 1976 and 1977 the actions of the ADC led to a breach of the then applying GATT skim milk powder minimum pricing arrangement.

The Government will not tolerate such activity, and the ADC has been formally directed to ensure that, in the fulfilment of its statutory functions and responsibilities, there is strict compliance with Australia's current responsibilities under the GATT International Dairy Agreement.

Accordingly, the Corporation has advised exporters that they are required to observe the GATT minimum prices when arranging the sale of dairy products. The Minister for Primary Industry has stated that he will have no hesitation in cancelling the export licences of any exporter reported to him by the ADC, who he finds to be in breach of these export conditions.

As I have already mentioned, the Auditor-General's report was referred to the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor. The reason for this was to seek the Crown Solicitor's opinion as to whether or not the Auditor-General's report disclosed a prima facie case on which any individual in Australia might be prosecuted. In his reply of 22 June 1982, the Crown Solicitor stated that on the material contained in the Auditor-General's report he did not think it was possible to conclude that there is prima facie evidence of the commission of any offence in Australia by any person.

The Crown Solicitor noted that there may, however, have been a breach of Singapore or Philippines law, but said that, as at present advised, he could see no useful purpose being served by pursuing this aspect of the matter.
From the Government's point of view, the question of a possible breach of Singapore or Philippines law is a matter for authorities of those countries.

However, as the Minister for Primary Industry stated to the Parliament on 29 October last year, the Government is most concerned that the agencies of statutory authorities abide by the letter and intent of the laws of the countries in which they operate, at all times.

Finally, in respect of this matter, honourable senators will note that there is a considerable difference of opinion between the Auditor-General and the ADC on certain aspects of the Auditor-General's report. I do not propose to canvass these differences of opinion. It is, however, worth pointing out that the ADC management group did find in its general overview that the summary of events prepared by the Auditor-General was, with some exceptions, a reasonable assessment of the circumstances.
Dairying Industry Stabilization Fund
I now turn to the matter of the ownership, future use and control of the Dairying Industry Stabilization Fund (DISF).
The Senate Standing Committee made several observations in respect of the DISF, and these can be summarised as follows:
No clear, undisputed evidence is available to show that any single group in the dairy industry is entitled to claim beneficial or legal 'ownership' of the funds .
So long as the DISF remains in existence, it should be expended in accordance with section 11 of the Dairying Industry Act.
If ADI is to be sold or ownership transferred in any way, the DISF should not be made available to any single group within the industry to purchase ADI.

As the co-operative and proprietary companies, which largely generated the funds which formed the basis for the DISF, have disappeared or merged with other proprietary or co-operative companies, the return of those funds would be administratively difficult and inequitable.
The Commonwealth Government, on behalf of the Australian taxpayers, is entitled to a claim to the ownership of the DISF which, at the very least, ranks equally with dairy industry groups.
The question of the 'ownership' of the DISF should be the subject of a more explicit statement by the Government than was made in the Minister for Primary Industry's memorandum of 26 June 1979.

Because the funds originally used to establish the DISF were derived from export sales of dairy produce and were, at that time, clearly the property of the industry, it would be difficult to justify a taxpayer claim on the present assets of the fund.

In his statement to the Parliament on 29 October 1981, the Minister for Primary Industry announced that he had asked his Department to meet with representatives of the ADC and the dairy industry to consider the Senate Committee's recommendations and to report to him on the matter. These discussions have now been completed, and agreement reached in May this year that the fund should continue to be used for the benefit of the industry generally, and in accordance with section 11 of the Dairying Industry Act.

To assist in clarifying the future use and control of the DISF, guidelines have been drawn up by the Department of Primary Industry in consultation with representatives of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference and the ADC. The Minister for Primary Industry has approved the guidelines and I hereby table a copy. Honourable Senators will note that expenditure from the Fund will continue to be on the recommendation of the ADC, after consultation with the Conference, and will require ministerial approval.
General Guidelines for Statutory Authorities

As honourable senators know, the Senate committee's report raises many general issues of principle such as ministerial control of statutory authorities, including powers of direction; the development of suitable guidelines for the establishment, operation and accountability of statutory authorities and subsidiary companies; the duties and responsibilities of members of such authorities and companies; and reporting requirements.

These general issues of principle have been under examination by an inter- departmental committee, but the Government has not yet completed its consideration on all aspects. When the task is completed, a statement will be made by the Government.
Breaches of the GATT Minimum Pricing Arrangements other than those under the HOMPI Arrangements

Documents tabled last November included a report by the ADC on the question of whether any breach of the GATT skim milk powder minimum pricing arrangements had occurred apart from those made under the HOMPI arrangements.

This ADC report drew attention, in respect of Corporation sales, to sales made to Mexico between June and November 1976 for which the lack of documentation on some aspects may have been a cover for a possible breach of the GATT minimum pricing arrangements. In respect of trader-to-trader sales the ADC reported that an exhaustive search has been made of the Corporation records but no trace could be found of the Certificates of Authority to Export skim milk powder for the period in question. Without this information the ADC could not establish that all exports were approved at or above the GATT minimum price. On the basis of this the Minister for Primary Industry asked his Department to investigate these matters further.

The Department of Primary Industry has now examined the records held by the ADC , including records of concessional adjustments available to major recombiners. It has reported that while it is possible to infer that certain sales made by the ADC to Mexico may have been in breach of the GATT minimum price, on the basis of the available documentation this is not certain.

However, there is evidence of ADC sales from April 1976 to July 1976 at the GATT agreement minimum price to Alaska Milk Industry Limited, in Thailand, accompanied by a rebate paid to Holland Canned Milk International, Alaska Milk's parent company. Whether or not this last arrangement involved a breach of the GATT agreement is open to question because the discount was paid to a third party. Nevertheless, from the ADC papers available, it appears that at the time the then senior management of the ADC believed that the GATT agreement was being breached by payment of this rebate.

The Department of Primary Industry also confirmed that the records now available within the ADC are inadequate to identify any trader-to-trader sales that may have breached the GATT agreement. A questionnaire has been sent to all licenced exporters in order to determine what records they have retained in respect of the period concerned. Responses to date indicate that it will be impossible to show whether or not there was any widespread breach of the GATT arrangements.
Other Matters

Mr President, in the Minister for Primary Industry's statement of 29 October 1981 and in the related documents that were tabled, it was indicated that work had not been completed on some matters. These were:
Guidelines for future borrowing and investment by ADI.
definition and documentation of the respective duties and responsibilities of ADC and ADI accounting staff in relation to ADI transactions.
a review of the desirability of ADI maintaining its Hong Kong presence
a review of the ADI Hong Kong accounting arrangements
conclusion of a management agreement with Thai Dairy Industries
review of employment conditions for ADI expatriate staff.
There has been considerable progress on these matters.

The borrowing and investment guidelines for ADI will be finalised when the Government has decided on the guidelines to apply to Statutory Authorities generally. Meanwhile, the situation with regard to borrowings and investments by ADI remains that no borrowings are to be undertaken without the approval of the Treasurer and the Minister for Primary Industry and no investment is to be undertaken without specific approval from the Minister for Primary Industry.
The respective duties and responsibilities of ADC and ADI accounting staff in relation to ADI transactions have been clarified and are now being fully documented.
So far as maintaining a Hong Kong presence is concerned, ADI management has undertaken a study of the commercial benefits and costs, and the ADI Board has now to consider this study.
As a result of the review of the ADI Hong Kong accounting arrangements, a number of changes have been implemented. These include:
revised procedures for processing financial transactions
an upgraded system of internal financial control in the Hong Kong office, which was developed in conjunction with the ADI auditors
revised procedures dealing with the frequency and nature of reporting on the utilisation of financial facilities

new procedures, developed in consultation with ADI auditors, for verifying ADI expenses in Australia, which have overcome the need for ADI auditors to qualify ADI financial statements on this aspect as in the past.
The possibility of computerising ADI accounts in the Hong Kong office was examined but computerisation was found to be uneconomic.
Negotiations are continuing with Thai Dairy Industries on the management agreement.
The review of employment conditions for expatriate ADI staff has been completed , resulting in greater standardisation of conditions.
Conclusion

Mr President, in conclusion, let me say that I believe we are approaching the end of a prolonged period of searching examination of the operations of the ADC and ADI. The Government has been determined to ensure that everything possible be done to shed light on past happenings and to establish the ground for proper operations in the future. Let me reiterate the action that has been taken:
In 1979, the Minister for Primary Industry decided that a review of the role and functions of the ADI and the joint venture operations should be undertaken.
The Minister accordingly sought an inspection and audit of the accounts and records of ADI by the Commonwealth Auditor-General under Section 63P of the Audit Act 1901.
The Auditor-General's report disclosed deficiencies in the management and operations of ADI and its dealings with the ADC.

The ADC established a special management committee to examine all aspects of the Auditor-General's report dealing with managerial and accounting practices of ADI. When the ADC reported on 26 October 1979 the Minister for Primary Industry concluded that action was immediately required to overcome deficiencies.

Detailed information was provided to the Parliament last year on the action that had been taken. On some matters, action was incomplete at that time and I have now indicated what further work has been done on these matters.

In September 1981, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations reported on the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Asian subsidiaries. The information disclosed in this report concerning a special account set up for the purpose of receiving moneys associated with rebates paid on skim milk powder sales to HOMPI was of concern. The Government was determined that as much information as possible should be obtained about this account. I therefore requested the Auditor-General to undertake a special examination of this matter.
The Auditor-General's latest report is now before the House.

Finally, I want to lay to rest once and for all claims that have been made by the Opposition that the Government has attempted to cover up aspects of this issue. This is completely untrue, and I want to emphasise that most forcibly. The Government has placed before the Parliament relevant documents relating to the entire issue. We have followed up on outstanding matters and have ensured the implementation of a whole range of administrative changes to improve the operations of the ADC and the ADI. It has, indeed, been a long and drawn out process, but this has largely been brought about by the need to ensure that all issues raised have been properly examined and fairly dealt with. Our emphasis now will be concentrated on ensuring that the reforms that have been implemented are doing the required job. If they are found to be deficient in this regard, then corrective action will be taken without delay.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
The statement refers to the tabling of various papers. I now table those papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement and associated reports tabled by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and tabled in the House of Representatives last week comprise the latest instalment in the continuing scandal of maladministration of the Australian dairy industry, of personal impropriety, and of corporate, departmental and ministerial negligence. It is more than three years since Bill Hayden raised in the House of Representatives the question of malfeasance within a statutory authority under the control of the then Minister, Mr Sinclair. He was promptly denounced for raising the issue, as I was on numerous subsequent occasions for pressing it in the Senate. There were strenuous attempts to cover up or trivialise the matter by an agricultural media which was at best negligent and at worst corrupt. Certainly Ronald Andersen's role could be fairly described as corrupt. It included a clear instance of perjury before a Senate committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The chief substance of the Minister's statement, the Auditor-General's report dated 27 April and subsequent comments thereon is the rebate paid by the Australian Dairy Corporation over more than two years on skim milk sales to Holland Milk Products Inc. On page 15 the report notes, I believe rather disturbingly, that although that rebate was paid from 1 July 1974, no formal authorisation can be found of that rebate in the minutes of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd or the Australian Dairy Corporation until 24 August 1976. The Auditor-General's report states:
Even though this approval was given some 18 months after commencement of shipments to HOMPI, to apply retrospectively, it remains the only formal approval for the payment of the $25 a tonne rebate.
On the same page the Auditor-General notes that the Skim Milk Powder Equalisation Advisory Committee minutes of 24 August 1976 included the following :

A draft letter from the Chairman to the Australian Dairy Corporation, outlining the past agreement with Holland Milk Inc., was read to the meeting, and it was agreed the Chairman be authorised to sign same.

The letter, the signing of which was authorised on 24 August 1976 was, oddly enough, the Auditor-General notes, dated 1 June 1976. So we have retrospective authorisation of both correspondence and rebates paid. On page 17 the Auditor- General details overpayments in the form of excessive discounts and rebates paid to HOMPI totalling almost a quarter of a million dollars. It notes in very many places the conflicting evidence given by various people associated with the industry at the time as to the nature of the rebate that was paid-whether it was additional to or in lieu of discounts which had previously been paid-and it dwells at some length on, to say the least, the very untidy administrative arrangements which had been followed by the Corporation over that long period. I stress that throughout this period the Department of Primary Industry had a member on the Board of the Corporation, ostensibly representing the Minister, the Government and the public.

The secondary issue arising-and, concerning the proper administration of government, the most important issue-from the payment of the rebate itself was the fact that as from April 1976 it was reported to the Board of the Corporation that the discount which was being provided to HOMPI had taken the price of the Australian product below the agreed GATT minimum price of $US350. There was a subsequent dispute, which was the subject of an inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, as to the time at which the Minister was made aware of that breach. There is no official record of the Minister having been made aware of that breach until the end of August 1976. There was a further dispute as to whether, when an arrangement was entered into in November 1976 between Mr Uytengsu, the HOMPI representative, and representatives of the Australian Dairy Corporation to continue surreptitiously paying the rebate from the equity built up in the Singapore account standing to the credit of the Australian Dairy Corporation, the Minister, subsequent to the middle of November 1976, was aware of a continuing breach of the GATT. I simply note that the Auditor-General's report does not dispute the finding of the Senate committee which investigated this matter, and which unanimously found that Mr Webster was more likely to have been telling the truth about that than Mr Sinclair.

The Auditor-General was unable to state with certainty the beneficiaries of what was ultimately $4m, which included an interest payment, which had been deposited in the bank account in Singapore. One million dollars of that Singapore bank account balance was paid to a numbered Swiss bank account, the ultimate beneficiaries of which the Auditor-General was unable to trace. We know that at the time this was going on the Minister was desperately short of money. The Auditor-General was unable to say with certainty who the ultimate beneficiaries of that untraceable $1m-untraceable beyond the payment to a numbered Swiss bank account-were. I guess it is as a guy said to me over the weekend: 'No wonder the Minister refused to give evidence to the Senate committee'.

There is a matter raised on page 22 of the Auditor-General's report which is, or could be, quite crucial to the question whether Minister Sinclair was aware of the continuing breach of the GATT through the surreptitious payment of a rebate from the Corporation's equity in the Singapore bank account. I refer to the quotation from a memorandum dated 13 October 1976 from Mr Webster to Mr Kennedy, the Financial Controller of the Australian Dairy Corporation. The memo stated:

Shipments of skim milk powder consigned to HOMPI, Philippines, invoiced on and after 1 June through to 30 September 1976, on which the $25 per tonne commission is payable, should be debited against the ADI/ADC Corporation share of the account currently held in Singapore.

This matter was raised at the Estimates Committee H meeting last Thursday. The officers present were asked whether a copy of that memo was forwarded to the Department and whether a copy of the memo was subsequently forwarded to the Ministers. I think it would be fair to say that the officers fudged the question on the grounds that a similar and near-identical question had already been placed on notice regarding that matter. The officers said that a reply had been prepared to that question and that copies either had been sent to the Minister or were about to be sent to the Minister. Of course, they would not disclose the substance of that reply. I do not know whether the Minister will make that reply available to the Parliament, whether he will refer it back for a different sort of reply or whether he will let the question languish on the Notice Paper indefinitely.

If it should be that a copy of that memo was sent to the Department and was not sent to the Minister the Department was yet again highly negligent. If it was sent to the Minister then the Minister clearly knew more than a month before the meeting between Australian Dairy Corporation representatives and Mr Uytengsu in the Philippines on 15 November 1976 of the surreptitious arrangements which had been made to continue paying the rebate in breach of GATT. If the Minister saw the memo there is irrefutable evidence that the Minister condoned that breach. The official Government defence of the Minister on this matter was that the Minister did not know of the continuing breach of GATT and, therefore, was not guilty.

We have been told over the last couple of days that Minister Sinclair's successor knew and was told about corruption in the meat inspection service. But he is not guilty either. The Minister who does not know is not guilty and the Minister who does know is not guilty! The only constant in the Government line on this matter is that no National Country Party Minister is ever guilty. I heard the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) say on the radio that he was very angry about something that was contained in the report of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry. It is now clear that the incident which made him angry was not Mr Nixon's negligence but the fact that the Royal Commissioner pointed the finger at Mr Nixon. That is like excusing the bank robber and blaming the cop who blew the whistle on him. As a newspaper columnist observed a couple of weeks ago, no Minister can be found guilty of impropriety under this Prime Minister unless he is caught with both hands in the till under an arc lamp , and even then it has to be shown live on television.

The report of the Auditor-General produced a lengthy response from the Australian Dairy Corporation which consisted mostly of nit picking. Apart from the nit picking, which constituted most of the response, and the identification of quite trivial error, one could not do better in rebutting the Dairy Corporation's attempted white-wash than to quote from the Auditor-General, who in a subsequent letter said:
The report has generated a remarkable resurgence of memory on the part of officers of the Corporation . . .

They were amazingly able to recall incidents that they could not recall when officers of the Auditor-General's office had questioned them before. The Solicitor-General, an office which is known to share broadly the judgment of the newspaper columnist who said that nobody in this Government is guilty unless he is caught under an arc lamp with both fists in the till, in a letter to the Minister of 22 June this year stated:
. . . it would not be possible, on the material contained in the report, to conclude that there is prima facie evidence on the commission of any offence in Australia by any person.
I emphasise the words 'by any person'. He went on to say:
If under Singapore or Philippines law there exist offences of the kind referred to in paragraph 6 above-
Paragraph 6 lists the offences as follows:
a defrauding of the company by the shareholders; and
a failure by the Directors of the company to act honestly and to use reasonable diligence in the affairs of the company.
He continued:
. . . there may well have been a breach of that law.
That is, the law of Singapore or the Philippines. The Solicitor-General continued:
But, as at present advised, I cannot see any useful purpose that would be served by pursuing this aspect of the matter.

That view was endorsed by the Minister in the statement which has just been tabled. If the laws of Singapore and the Philippines have been broken that is a matter for the governments of those countries to take up. I suppose that is a truism. We cannot prosecute people for breaches of the laws of Singapore or the Philippines, but it ought to be a matter of concern to this Government that there is a prima facie case against its agents-the members of the Dairy Corporation and the directors of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd are agents of the Government of Australia-of breaches of the law of Singapore and the Philippines. With one minor exception to which I will refer later-a person who was not directly associated with any of these matters-nobody involved in politics, the bureaucracy or the industry has been in any way disciplined by the Government for those offences.

Maladministration of the Department of Primary Industry or of the dairy industry did not cease with the departure of the previous Minister in September 1979. It was subsequently revealed that in December 1981 Mr Nixon had intervened to waive a penalty against Murray-Goulburn Co-operative Ltd, in which he was a shareholder. There was, among other things, a prima facie breach of the Bowen guidelines to which Ministers in this Government are supposed to adhere. On 4 and 5 May of this year it was reported to a meeting of the Corporation board that one dairy company-and, it was subsequently discovered, about five other dairy companies-had failed to repay Reserve Bank of Australia advances when the product against which the money was advanced had been sold. Again, Murray- Goulburn was an offender. According to the Minister, he was told of that breach of the Reserve Bank loan conditions on 17 May. The officer present at the meeting of the Corporation board on 4 and 5 May-Mr Thorn, if I remember correctly-in a manner reminiscent of Al Wallace before the Senate Standing Commitee on Finance and Government Operations, offered less than unequivocal endorsement of the Minister's claim that he had not been told of the matter until 17 May. That occurred before Estimates Committee H last Thursday.

Under the regime of the present Minister more than a year ago the Australian Dairy Corporation received a firm offer of $US10m for its equity in PT Indomilk. The contract for the sale which had been signed was, not surprisingly, conditional upon no objections being raised by the Indonesian Government or the Australian Minister. The Australian Minister intervened to prevent that sale from proceeding. It is claimed that the Indonesian Government would not have permitted the sale to proceed. That may or may not be true. However, the point is that the Indonesian Government was never given the opportunity to pass judgment on the matter because the Australian Minister intervened first. As a result of that intervention, the Australian Dairy Corporation has forgone $US10m for its equity in the company. I know that quite recently the General Manager of the Australian Dairy Corporation warned that the company-that is PT Indomilk- could go into bankruptcy and there would be little if any equity left for the Australian partner, the Australian Dairy Corporation.

So it is likely that as a direct result of further meddling by the present Minister for Primary Industry, for reasons which he has deigned not even to explain, the Dairy Industry Stabilisation Fund will have lost $US10m. The affairs of the dairy industry and the Ministers responsible in recent years are a veritable encyclopaedia of chicanery. The only person punished in any way as a result of all this was Mr Pyle who falsified his travel claims to the Corporation or, if one prefers his version, disconnected the speedo on the Corporation's car. If one looks objectively at that case in isolation, of course Mr Pyle deserves more punishment than he got. He should not have been left on the Corporation board. But he may well ask the question: 'Why have I alone been singled out for any discipline or punishment?' Of course, Mr Nixon's permissive view of Pyle's behaviour, or of Pyle's misconduct, is totally consistent with his later response to disclosures by Mr Kelly of bribery and corruption in the meat inspection service. Having set a new standard of permissiveness in the Pyle case, and in the Australian Dairy Corporation in general-or having had new standards of permissiveness set for him by his predecessor-Mr Nixon then followed those standards in his judgment on the allegations made by Mr Kelly. The final cost of that piece of ministerial negligence, when subsequently the Americans find out about it, is likely to be a great deal more than the $US10m lost to the dairy industry because of Mr Nixon's intervention in the sale of the Dairy Corporation's equity in PT Indomilk.

There are matters raised in the Auditor-General's report which I believe merit further investigation. In particular, to cite just one, I refer to what is euphemistically referred to as the management fee applied to the account in the Singapore bank into which the rebate and some other payments were directed. There is conflicting evidence, according to the Auditor-General, from the two parties principally concerned as to what happened to what is described as the management fee. This raises two questions: Firstly, whether the management fee is a payment that ought to have been made and, secondly, even if the management fee payment was legitimate, whether the people who finally received those funds were entitled to them. For that, among other reasons, I move the following amendment:

Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the matters raised in the Minister's statement and the papers tabled by him be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for further investigation and report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take part in this discussion of the statement of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) referring to the Australian Dairy Corporation and to Australia's dairy industry. I am afraid that this appears to be an area in which considerable investigation has been seen to be necessary as a result of various occurrences. In fairness, I believe also that it is an area in which there has been a great measure of investigation in an attempt to ensure that Australia's trading guidelines in the field of the dairy industry are in accordance with the trading guidelines that we as a signigicant trading nation seek to follow with our trading partners all around the world. But I am afraid that when we are discussing matters of trade in various parts of the world very often circumstances arise that may not appear to be totally in line with what we all seek to establish. When that becomes the circumstance, of course a real measure of emotion enters into the discussion and perhaps we may tend to lose a little of our perspective.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that there can be any questioning of the purpose or determination of the Minister in this exercise. The Minister has a very deep- seated and long-existing knowledge of the very industry under discussion. Over and above that, of course, the industry that we are discussing is one of Australia's most basic industries. It is of very great significance not only in the internal Australian economy but also in our capacity to establish overseas credit. We would also be aware that over the years this industry has suffered significantly from fierce competition. I think we should remind ourselves from time to time, as we seek to follow the dicatates of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade-that Agreement, of course, is basic to the final effective operation of international trade-that in many circumstances and in many places around the world those very guidelines, essential as they are, are under a significant measure of threat.

I refer, for example, to the trading relationships of entities such as the European Economic Community, although this may not directly involve the guidelines of GATT. One of the enormous problems that confront the rest of the trading world and certainly must tend to throw very great strain on the capacity of the trading world to maintain and develop the trading guidelines of GATT is the actions which occur when we see, for instance, very significant subsidised surpluses coming from the European Community, entering the field of international trade and competing totally unfairly in that area. I mention these things in order that we might seek to be aware of the sorts of strains and tensions that occur when responsible people, representing a great Australian industry, seek to maintain and develop markets in what in many cases can only be described as unfortunate and very difficult conditions. Perhaps in some parts of the trading world there is an acceptance of standards that are in some measure alien to the standards which we seek to establish and adopt.

The statement that the Senate has before it this afternoon-I have barely had time to read it in any detail-refers to many of the problems that have been highlighted, I believe, by the investigation of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations into these matters. It has identified various areas that have been referred to. I believe that if we take a fair and responsible view of the issue we will agree that it seems that as to the problems that have been highlighted over the past several years-back to 1976-77 at least-appropriate and strong action has been taken. Indeed, problems that have been identified have been overcome as a result of the Government's determinations following these various investigations.

The Holland Milk Products Inc. arrangements, of course, are quite central to the issue of this debate this afternoon. My information seems to show that the ADC holds only 13 1/3 per cent of the share capital in HOMPI, whilst 23 1/3 per cent of that capital is held by the Holland Canned International Milk Company, a Dutch dairy manufacturing organisation, and the balance-the significant majority of share capital-is held by an entity known as G.F. Equity Inc. In the period 1974 to 1977-that is when the Australian dairy industry seemed to be so involved in these investigations and discussions-the Australian Dairy Corporation was a major supplier of skim milk to the HOMPI organisation. It appears that at least in some of those negotiations there has been a rebate of some $25 a tonne. This rebate has applied to some-I am not sure whether it is a significant number but certainly to some-ADC shipments of skim milk powder to the HOMPI organisation. That rebate has been paid to a bank account in Singapore.

The Minister involved has sought the widest and most responsible information he can get on this whole matter. The Auditor-General was requested to investigate the rebate situation on, I understand, 10 November 1981. He reported on 27 April this year. A typographical error occurred in the report and a correction was made on 11 August 1982. The audit examination of the Australian Dairy Produce Board, as it then was-it became the Australian Dairy Corporation-found that there were certain problems within that operative. ADC and Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd contracted to supply-this was a significant contract-some 12,000 tonnes a year of skim milk powder to HOMPI, a Philippine based organisation. To September 1976 there were credit notes to the value of approximately $3.07m, including $1.84m in approved price adjustments and $689,500 in rebates, together with a 2 per cent commission.

It does appear that these matters have been identified. The purpose of the Auditor-General's investigation was to seek an explanation of these problems which clearly appeared to the Minister to require some real and proper investigation and consideration. The Auditor-General commented on some improper management and accounting arrangements within the ADC and ADI in the 1976-77 period. The result, of course, was that, at the request of the Minister, the Australian Dairy Corporation established a special management committee to examine and report on the management and accounting practices of this particular organisation. Its report was acted upon on 29 October 1981. That was one of several occasions on which the Minister concerned acted promptly and appropriately in having matters that could well have been problem matters examined and reported and recommended upon.

The question of the Swiss bank account to which Senator Walsh referred could well have some connection with the Dutch part in the HOMPI organisation. The Solicitor-General is concerned that perhaps Singapore and Philippines law may be involved and may indeed have been breached by the contractual or trading arrangements between HOMPI and the Australian Dairy Corporation. Indeed, the Philippines tax office at this moment has requested certain detail from Australia in that particular area and a significant investigation in that field is under way. The Government would naturally be extremely concerned at any possibility of breaching the laws of some other country with whom Australia may be a trading partner; indeed, with breaching the laws of any other country, regardless of any specific trading relationship. The Government has at all times expressed a very real concern that statutory authorities, important though they may be and important though the task they perform is, abide by all appropriate laws. Basically I believe that statutory authorities in this country in the marketing field have performed and are performing tasks of very great value, not only to the industries they represent but also to the total Australian economy.

It seems to me that the concern of the Government that these authorities remain well and truly within the laws not only of their own country but also of the countries with which they trade is a matter of prime importance and quite clearly it is a matter of which the Minister himself is well aware. But as indeed happens in so many fields in which we find ourselves involved with a judgment, with a determination of the law, in this case there is a confusion and something of a difference of opinion between the Australian Dairy Corporation and the Auditor-General's views in certain areas. These matters will be discussed further and illuminated in the days and weeks ahead.

The Dairy Industry Stabilization Fund was an area under some considerable comment. The Department, the ADC and the industry have consulted at length and in considerable detail on this matter and have decided that the Fund should continue to be used to the benefit of the industry generally and that it should operate within section 11 of the Dairying Industry Act.

I do not want to continue this debate this afternoon at great length. All I want to maintain is that, in what can only be described sometimes as significantly strained circumstances in international trade, it is not always certain that the absolute guidelines of the GATT will be observed, even though it is the instruction of this Government, the very determined and definite instruction of this Government and, in this case, of the Minister concerned, that we as a country must always operate within those guidelines. There are circumstances when there are strains, when there are measures of urgency to find a market, almost any market, for surpluses that may well be embarrassing, may well be crucial to the survival of significant industries. In these circumstances, emotion and problems have occurred and will no doubt continue to occur. But what is abundantly clear is that the Minister has on all occasions acted promptly and determinedly when some form of, perhaps, indiscretion or some unusual procedure has been brought to his attention. It is the purpose of the Government that that sort of investigation will continue, that Australia will remain a significant trader, as indeed it must always be, within the basic rules of international trade. The great tragedy of international trade is that some of the strains that are placed upon it are strains that are placed upon it by people who decide to trade right outside the very rules that are the basic concern of this particular Government and the industries of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like most really important scandals-those showing incompetence, corruption and negligence, eating right into the heart of the government-the facts involved in the dairy industry scandal are complex, difficult to follow and difficult to retain. It is easy to lose sight of the wood for the trees. But I do not believe that they are as complex as all that. I do not believe that the salient points cannot be summarised in about half a dozen propositions which reveal just how much difficulty the Government is in as a result of these reports. In coming to grips with the basic issues, I think it is necessary to look at the relevant findings of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations and weigh them against the findings of the Auditor-General and, to some extent, the Crown Solicitor, who participated in the Government investigation which is the subject of this statement.

SPEECH.PARA: The first relevant finding of the Senate Committee is that during 1976-77, during the period Mr Ian Sinclair was Minister for Primary Industry, by virtue of a secret rebate arrangement with its Filipino trading partner, HOMPI-Holland Milk Products Inc.-and possibly also in relation to other overseas trading partners, Australia was in significant breach of its international trading obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. That finding of the Senate Committee is fully confirmed by the report now before us and acknowledged to be intolerable by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) who put down the statement. The second crucial finding of the Senate Committee was as to the extent of ministerial involvement in that particular breach of international trade law. As to the question of whether the Minister, Mr Sinclair knew of and approved of the illegal arrangement, there was a conflict between the Minister and the then Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation, Mr Webster, which the Committee resolved by concluding that 'on the balance of probabilities Mr Sinclair's recollection of the events was not as reliable as that of Mr Webster'; a damning conclusion, and one that was, of course, the subject of very considerable political controversy at the time.

As to that conclusion and as to the question of the Minister's involvement, there are, of course, no further findings in the Auditor-General's report or any of the other material before us today. But certainly it should be acknowledged and put on record that there is absolutely nothing in any of those findings to contradict or undermine the conclusion of the Senate Committee as to the Minister's culpability. The third finding of the Senate Committee--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all irrelevant.

—It might be irrelevant to Senator Chaney but it is very embarrassing to the Government and I do not doubt for a moment that he is squirming when he hears references to the role of Mr Sinclair in this matter.
—Are you suggesting the report should have confirmed or denied, either way?

—I am suggesting that, given the amount of digging about that the Auditor-General's staff quite properly did in the discharge of their duties to get to the bottom of the rebate arrangements and the circumstances that surrounded them, if there had been evidence of a character which could have got Mr Sinclair off the hook there is no doubt that it would have emerged during the course of this inquiry. The fact that it did not has a significance that honourable senators can judge for themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: The third simple proposition to emerge from this saga is the clear finding of the Senate Committee that there were manifest inadequacies and improprieties in the general management and the general accounting practice of the Australian Dairy Corporation and Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Limited during the period in question-again, of course, during which period Mr Sinclair was the responsible Minister. That particular finding is fully and, indeed, explicitly confirmed in the language of the Minister in his tabling statement today.

The fourth crucial proposition to emerge from the Senate Committee report was that one of the improprieties, or at least inadequately documented aspects, of the ADC's financial management related to its payment of rebates, commissions and price reduction commitments, amounting in all to some $3m, to its Filipino trading partner, HOMPI. The payments in question-most notoriously the $25 a tonne rebate, which was the amount immediately involved in Australia's breach of GATT-were made, as the Senate Committee found, not to HOMPI itself, which was the company immediately, contractually, if one likes, entitled to those rebates and commissions, but rather to a Singapore bank account operated by two individuals, both of them directors of HOMPI but more immediately playing the role of the principals of HOMPI's majority shareholder, a company called G.F. Equity Inc. That was the set of transactions-the payment of those moneys to this obscure Singapore bank account operated by individuals having no formal authority from the company to which the money should have been paid-which raised , of course, a whole series of questions as to who was benefiting from this highly unusual financial arrangement. What the Senate Committee could do was no more than raise questions of those kinds.

What the report before us today and the findings of the Auditor-General have established is that there was definitely $3m-in fact a little more than that when we take into account the interest payments which accumulated on the funds in question-paid in this way and that the accounts were treated in the way that the Senate Committee suggested had been the case. This in fact is confirmed by the Auditor-General's report.

The fifth point associated with that that was made by the Senate Committee was that in the disbursement of those moneys that found their way into the Singapore bank account serious improprieties may have occurred. The Senate Committee was told that the arrangement was that the moneys in question were to be disbursed to the three companies which constituted HOMPI shareholders, and disbursed in proportions which represented the respective equity in HOMPI of the three companies involved. That is to say, G.F. Equity was to get 60 per cent of the moneys accumulated in this account, the Dutch company Holland Canned Milk International was to get 26 2/3 per cent and the Australian Dairy Corporation, which was a 13 1/3 per cent shareholder, was to get that proportion of the moneys in question. The Senate Committee found itself reasonably satisfied that the amount standing to the credit of the ADC was in fact fully credited to ADC, albeit only in the form of continuing illegal rebates on subsequent shipments of skim milk. The Committee was not satisfied, however, that the balance of the moneys in question was in fact fully and properly credited to the other shareholders, especially the Dutch company Holland Canned Milk, but found itself unable to take that matter any further.

One of the key matters dealt with in the Auditor-General's report is the disbursement of the moneys in the Singapore bank account. Some very interesting new things emerge from the Auditor-General's report in that respect. The Auditor -General's report, which is accompanied in this respect by a Crown Solicitor's opinion which I will come to in a moment, confirms that there may have been spectacular improprieties in the disbursement of that money from that bank account in Singapore. In the first place there is no evidence at all that the moneys were disbursed at any stage or in any proportion to Holland Canned Milk. The nearest thing that can be established is that sums totalling just over $1m were sent to a Swiss bank for and on behalf of an anonymous account holder in that bank. Who ended up getting what out of this little arrangement, out of that little sum, is a matter that remains one for fascinating speculation.

The second thing that emerges from the Auditor-General's account of the way in which these moneys were disbursed is the new information that the pool from which the moneys were credited back from this account to the ADC and possibly to the other shareholders was in fact reduced by 10 per cent. Ten per cent of the gross funds in the Singapore bank account, put there by the Australian Dairy Corporation as part of its secret commissions and rebates to HOMPI, was extracted from the pool, totalling some $406,000-to be precise $405,971-before the moneys were credited to ADC, sent off to Swiss bank accounts or dealt with in other mysterious ways. The reduction of the moneys in that account by that percentage sum raises questions as to not only the implications of this for the ADC getting its hands on its ahare of the total sum which was credited to that account, but also more immediately as to who got the benefit of that little piece of largess. Who was the beneficiary of the $406,000 that was taken out of the moneys in the Singapore bank account before they were dealt with in the other ways in question? The Auditor-General was unable to find out. He asked Mr Uytengsu, the HOMPI principal and G. F. Equity principal, who is the man in the middle of all of this in the Philippines. Mr Uytengsu says that this sum of money, this 10 per cent, this $406,000, constituted something mysteriously described as an 'M bonus' and amounted in fact to an incentive bonus to management and key personnel of the Filipino company. It is an interesting question as to who constituted 'key personnel' for this purpose. Mr McCartney, the other key figure in this whole series of negotiations, who was at all relevant times a director of HOMPI, had a different view as to what this $406, 000 had been taken out of the pool in the Singapore bank account for. He said it was in the nature of a management fee paid to G. F. Equity, just one of the three shareholder companies. Both Mr McCartney and Mr Uytengsu apparently denied that any HOMPI director got his hands on any of that money. But it remains quite obscure, in the absence of any other positive information supplied to the Auditor-General or to anyone else by Mr Uytengsu or anyone else, as to who got what. It is a very large and very interesting question that remains to be resolved in this particular way. What is clear is that just over $400,000 of this particular slush fund stood available to anyone whom Mr Uytengsu and his friends wanted to pay off in Australia or elsewhere to facilitate their trading arrangements. Again, it can only for the moment be a matter for speculation as to who was paid off with that particular sum of money or proportions of it.

Finally, it was a matter of further concern to the Senate Committee, and evident concern to the Government, that not only improprieties may have occurred in the disposition of these funds from the Singapore account but also that actual illegalities may have occurred.

It was in this respect that the Crown Solicitor was in fact asked to advise the Government. I do not know how long the Government had to wait for the advice in this respect but the document that has been tabled is dated 22 June 1982. The relevant part of that document states:

If funds belonging to a company operating in Australia were distributed in this country to shareholders of the company in circumstances corresponding to those in which the proceeds of $25 rebate were apparently distributed, either in Singapore or the Philippines, to the shareholders of Hompi, it is likely that offences in at least two areas would have been committed:
(a) a defrauding of the company by the shareholders; and
(b) a failure by the Directors of the company to act honestly and to use reasonable diligence in the affairs of the company.

Mr O'Donovan, the Crown Solicitor, did not descend to any more detail in his opinion to enable us to formulate a more precise understanding as to exactly how the law in question, in his opinion, might have operated had this transaction occurred in Australia. But he did state clearly in a subsequent paragraph that he did not think any offence under Australian law was constituted by these events since they involved overseas companies acting outside Australia. However, he did raise the question as to whether or not there may be breaches of law in the Philippines or Singapore. He said it was impossible and inappropriate for him to follow up that question further.

We have at the very least behaviour which on the face of it, had it occurred in Australia, would have constituted a breach, presumably a clear breach, of Australian law and behaviour which may well have constituted not only impropriety but also a breach of the law of the countries with which Australia was trading. That, of course, is an intolerable situation. That was acknowledged , I am happy to make clear, by the Minister himself in his statement when he said:
. . . the Government is most concerned that the agencies of statutory authorities abide by the letter and intent of the laws of the countries in which they operate, at all times.

That, of course, is a sentiment with which the Opposition fully agrees. Other matters are dealt with in the report and in the material tabled, and many other aspects of maladministration are revealed in the very detailed documentation now on the table. But it should also be said that in addition to the matters in this report there are in fact a number of other matters, including some of quite fundamental policy significance-for example, the provision of appropriate guidelines to govern the conduct of statutory authorities engaged in commercial trading activities-upon which the Minister has not reported in this statement or in any of the accompanying documentation. The Minister has not given us an indication of when we can expect to get reports on the many outstanding matters to which he referred and listed his statement. He simply took a rain-check on those matters.

For this reason alone, I suggest to the Senate that it is appropriate that the whole question raised by the dairy industry scandal go back to the Senate Standing Commitee on Finance and Government Operations, as Senator Walsh suggested, for further review. The main reason this whole matter needs further detailed consideration by the Committee is that it does clearly reveal a continuing sorry saga of maladministration in both the Department of Primary Industry and the relevant statutory authority. Some of the detail of that maladministration relates to the past and has not yet come to light. I refer here in this particular respect to the circumstances surrounding the disbursement of the funds in the Singapore bank account and as to who got what, in particular who in Australia might have got what, out of that slush fund and, in particular, the amount of $406,000 which remains utterly unaccountable for.

In addition to the scrutiny and further investigation of matters presumably past there is some question as to maladministration that continues in the Department and in the authority. The footnote to the letter to the Deputy Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet from the Auditor- General's Office dated 10 August 1982 is very revealing in this respect. This is the further letter from the Auditor-General's Office in which the Auditor- General's Office laid out its response to what, in turn, had been the Australian Dairy Corporation's response to the original report of the Auditor-General. The First Assistant Auditor-General, Mr Monaghan, who signed this letter, said:

There is only one other comment that we would make. Many of the observations by the Corporation relate to details of little, if any, consequence, but we note that the report has generated a remarkable resurgence of memory on the part of officers of the Corporation who, during the audit investigation, found themselves unable to offer more than the barest modicum of information to the audit team.

That is a very revealing paragraph and a very important proposition for the Senate Committee to consider. It clearly suggests-it is rather politely stated but it could not be articulated more clearly-the view of the Auditor-General that information was being withheld deliberately from the Auditor-General's Office during its inquiry-information which the Auditor-General's Office found by other means, by travelling overseas and examining the papers and material for itself, and which then, and only then, was responded to by the officers of the statutory corporation in question. If that is what is going on, if information comes out of a statutory corporation only when it has to be squeezed out or pulled out an inch at a time in a way which so obviously has been the case here, then it seems to me and to the Opposition that that is evidence of continuing serious maladministration and continuing serious fault in the Australian Dairy Corporation-serious fault which ought to be, at the very least, the subject of further investigation by the Senate Committee.

The Australian Dairy Corporation and the whole Australian dairy industry issue resume their place on the list. This matter is right up there with tax evasion; it is right up there with the meat industry scandal in demonstrating the incompetence and incapacity of this Government to be the government of this nation. Like Mr Howard and Senator Durack on the tax issue, like Mr Nixon in relation to the meat industry issue, here again we have Mr Sinclair revealed as presiding over a hopelessly incompetent department and statutory authority. We have a Minister turning a blind eye to manifest maladministration in his department. We have here, as in these other matters before the Parliament today and in recent weeks, a Minister not asking the right questions at the right times. We have a Minister certainly not acknowledging that he ever received the right answers to those questions at the relevant times.

The reality is that this Government's administration has become a scandal in every direction that one looks-as far as the eye can see. In department after department, in authority after authority and in ministerial office after ministerial office there is a stench of scandal in the air. Minister after Minister, department after department and authority after authority have revealed standards of incompetence, negligence and corruption that would have been beyond anyone's wildest imagination as taking place within the Australian Government and bureaucracy before the Fraser Government came to power. This is the kind of legacy that the Fraser Government has laid down for the future government of this country. This is the burden that the Fraser Government will bear when it finally accounts for its stewardship to the Australian people at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that I will not be able to treat the chamber to such a collection of extravagant hyperbole as that to which we have just listened. I wish briefly to speak to the statement presented by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in relation to Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd. I had intended to provide some information on the business details but I think they have been covered adequately already by earlier speakers in this debate. Accordingly, I think it is better that I concentrate my remarks on what one might call the generalities of the issue. The amount of information that is becoming available even now continues to grow. When I read the information available I found that there was no new material which I would regard as throwing any more light on the whole matter. It generally seems to be some sort of a rehash and a refinement. There is certainly very little that I would say adds anything to the position as we knew it 12 months or 2 years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: It would help at a time like this to go back to when Asia Dairy Industries was in its prime, one might say. I think we need to consider what the dairy industry in Australia was like in 1976. I remember that when I entered Parliament in the beginning of 1976 the first people who came to my office said that they had received a notification from their dairy company that they would be paid 38c a lb for that season. As honourable senators would be well aware, that was an absolute disaster to the industry at that time. Due to the European Economic Community and to Great Britain's changed buying policy, due to falling prices and a world oversupply, the industry in Australia was absolutely crumbling. The Australian Dairy Corporation and the industry generally strove to achieve the best possible results they could for the Australian dairy farmer. I think we have to remember that it was in the interests of the industry that arrangements were made to achieve this. Of late I have not heard that mentioned.

The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations carried out an investigation some 12 or 18 months ago but again did not get to the background of what went on behind the operations of the Asia Dairy Industries business. I think it would help if I covered a little of that history. We have to take into account that whole milk powder at that stage had a General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade value of $350 a tonne, and any milk that was not sold at that price, attained about $120 a tonne. It is all very well to look at whether $350 a tonne was a realistic price or whether it could have been obtained, but that was the position. I do not support, and neither does the Government, any breaches of GATT. I think we all agree that close attention to our obligations under this treaty is very important. I appreciate that at all times the Australian Dairy Corporation acted in a manner that would maximise the export returns to Australian dairy farmers. I have never heard that questioned and I believe that it needs to be taken into account. The Corporation, the industry generally and the departmental officers were certainly doing everything possible for the industry. Between them they engineered the transition of the industry from being a price taking, totally export oriented industry to the new streamlined, efficient and fairly profitable industry that it is today. This was all achieved during this period we are talking about. The industry is sound today. Our thanks must go to those who got us through the latter part of the 1970s.

Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd was established to provide a product outlet in an area of the world that appeared to have a growing export potential. The arrangements that were made were certainly novel so far as the Australian primary industry trade was concerned. They were more than novel; they were probably unique at that stage. Knowing what we do now, with the benefit of hindsight, we may not have considered that it was desirable to operate the same type of business in the same way. When the enterprise was set up it was thought that it was very good and no objections were received from anybody in or around industry or government. But now almost everybody has become an expert.

I think we also need to consider that business in the East is different from that in Western countries. I think that is fully understood by some people but certainly not by all. When we introduced extra nationalities into trading with the East, as in this case, the differences become more marked and, in turn, even less understood. The fact that the Australian interest was a Commonwealth instrumentality provided extra complications that could have been eliminated had that not been the case and, say, it had been a private industry but it was not. We have to accept the fact that it had to fit in with what one might call the normal trading practices of the area and act in common with its trading partners . Whether or not we agree-in many cases we certainly would not-people who are accustomed to dealing in the East, and particularly those in the private business sector, know only too well of the extraordinary type of negotiating that is necessary if they want to do business there. I again remind honourable senators of the alternatives: We sold the powder in that area either at $350 a tonne or at $120 a tonne. I think we should not lose sight of the amounts involved, a point that was never made by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations.

This chamber has, over a period, heard a lot on this matter. Those of us who have had an interest in the dairy industry I think know all the parties by name very well. I think that we are in a position to know what is happening in this matter. We have heard considerable repetition about various matters. Honourable senators opposite have repeated their same old speeches and comments on many occasions without really throwing much light on the subject. This statement demonstrates both the Government's and the Minister's attention to the matter and their desire to have it completely clarified. The Government has taken steps to see that the points that are raised are clarified, and it will continue to do so. TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a most remarkable defence by Senator Archer of breaches--

It may be that, in order to secure such trade, the temptation is there to undertake certain arrangements. That is the whole question at issue. I do not intend to undertake yet another rehash of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. That has already been well dealt with by Senator Walsh and Senator Evans. It needs to be said also that neither the Opposition nor any honourable senator in this chamber wishes Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd ill. No one was more delighted than I was to read in the Melbourne Age of 28 July this year that Asia Dairy Industries appeared to be making a big comeback. What the Senate has before it-my remarks will take only a few minutes because, as I have said, much of the ground has already been covered-are those documents that have been tabled today for its consideration. It is true that that report was made, as the Auditor-General has said, in the absence of full documentation. Because of the lapse of time he was unable to be absolutely firm about the intentions of some parties or to come to firm conclusions about a number of aspects of the matter. As I have said, I do not want to give the details of his conclusions. The point is that as at 27 April, when the report was presented to the Government, the Auditor-General, who was appointed by this Parliament to conduct an absolutely impartial, independent investigation of the functions of government and the proper discharge of duties- particularly with regard to funds of the magnitude of which we are discussing- found an absence of full documentation and, because of the lapse of time, difficulty in ascertaining the intention of parties.

That report was put down on 27 April 1982. It was responded to, in a rather thick document dated 12 July 1982 by the Australian Dairy Corporation. I have had, in the hour or so available to me to look through all of these documents, only the briefest opportunity to examine that response. Its general conclusion, in commenting on the report of the Auditor-General, can be summarised by saying that the Auditor-General was suffering from certain misapprehensions because of certain errors of fact and because inferences which he drew would not have been drawn had he taken advantage of a fuller opportunity to understand the true nature of the trading situations obtaining at the time. It is claimed that he could have found that fuller understanding by proper consultation with officers or former officers of the Australian Dairy Corporation. The sequence of events was: the Auditor-General came to certain conclusions but admitted deficiencies due to inadequate documentation and the lapse of time affecting memory. He was then chastised in the Australian Dairy Corporation's response and reprimanded for not making fuller use of opportunities, said to be available to him, to acquaint himself with the full picture. We now have available a further response by the Auditor-General in which, amongst other things, he states:

Many of the observations by the Corporation relate to details of little, if any, consequence, but we note that the report has generated a remarkable resurgence of memory on the part of officers of the Corporation who, during the audit investigation, found themselves unable to offer more than the barest modicum of information to the audit team.

I believe that is an extremely damning indictment of the officers of the Corporation. It is restrained, but in the sharpest language I have yet come across in my time as a senator, in the course of intra-bureaucratic warfare. Clearly, there is an allegation of a most definite cover-up and of non-co- operation on the part of Australian Dairy Corporation officers in relation to the inquiry of the Auditor-General, who has been established by the Parliament as an independent, impartial officer to carry out the investigations assigned to him.

I make the point-and here I agree with Senator Archer-that a lot of documentation is before us this afternoon. I believe that the Senate is not in a position to resolve this continuing dispute between the Corporation and the Auditor-General.
