Very properly, therefore, the dispute should be referred to the Senate Committee which is personed by honourable senators who are, by their experience in the course of a former investigation--

TALK.START.PARA: —Personed?

—I cannot remember whether there is a lady on the Committee, which is personed by honourable senators who have, as a result of a former investigation, experience and understanding of the background which would enable them to pursue this matter further.

SPEECH.PARA: Another document which gives, I believe, cause for some concern is that from the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor, Mr O'Donovan, dated 22 June 1982. Having reviewed the Auditor-General's report, he stated:

If funds belonging to a company operating in Australia were distributed in this country to shareholders of the company in circumstances corresponding to those in which the proceeds of the $25 rebate were apparently distributed, either in Singapore or the Philippines, to the shareholders of Hompi, it is likely that offences in at least two areas would have been committed:
(a) a defrauding of the company by the shareholders; and
(b) a failure by the Directors of the company to act honestly and to use reasonable diligence in the affairs of the company.

As I understand it, the Crown Solicitor is not saying that nothing illegal was done; he is saying that there was a defrauding of the company by the shareholders and there was a failure by the directors of the company to act honestly and to use reasonable diligence in the affairs of the company. This needs to be clearly understood. That charge is being laid by the Crown Solicitor but I understand him to be saying that because the events relating to those fraudulent activities, to those dereliction of duty activities, took place outside Australia there is no jurisdiction within the Australian legal system to bring these matters to a legal conclusion in our courts. In other words, there is illegality but it is not justiciable. That is a very important point to make and it should not be thought for one moment that the Crown Solicitor has given a clean bill of conduct to the directors of the company concerned. As I say, it is merely that the matters are not justiciable in our courts. The fact that they are not justiciable in our courts should not prevent a Senate standing committee from pursuing the matter in its own way. We therefore have revealed a situation whereby there is no laying to rest of the matters which have already been the subject of report by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. The Senate is still entitled to be uneasy, the Parliament is entitled to be uneasy and certainly the general public is entitled to be uneasy.

There is yet another matter to be considered. It concerns the allegation that the Australian Government has intervened in a way which prevents the sale of an Australian interest in a dairy company in Indonesia for some $10m and, instead, in compliance with the wishes of the Indonesian Government, is trying to negotiate or will go along with a deal to sell to another person in Indonesia that same interest for $4.5m. The inquiry which the Senate Committee wants to undertake has been deferred because of legal action pending in Australian and Indonesian courts.

The general point I am making is that the subject matter of these papers is apt for further consideration and investigation by our Senate Committee. I believe it will help to maintain that surveillance which is so obviously necessary on the part of the Parliament, given the inadequacies of administration and surveillance revealed at both the departmental and ministerial levels. For that reason, I support the amendment moved by Senator Walsh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to the statement made in the other place and presented here by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in relation to a number of papers, but I respond basically to the initial report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations on the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Asian subsidiaries. I pick up one point mentioned by Senator Tate, that the Parliament and probably the people of Australia will still feel uneasy even following the tabling of these documents. I believe that that is correct. Having read all of this documentation the final feeling is one of unease. However, I do not think it is permissible to leap from that to an indictment of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We have operating here an extremely complex situation, part of which involves a commercial operation, part of which involves a corporation and only a small part of which involves the Department of Primary Industry. The documentation and the investigations carried out by a number of Government bodies, such as the Auditor -General's Office, would seem to have exhausted all possible leads in trying to track down whether or not there have been any illegal activities on the part of Australians in the employ of the Government, its corporations or its commercial operations. They do not seem to have been able to find that such was the case. It is beyond doubt that there were breaches of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Although all of the documentation seems to take a fairly soft line on that, there is sufficient evidence to suggest that there were breaches of GATT. To that extent the Government is involved because under its international treaties it has a responsibility to other governments to maintain surveillance over the operations of government or semi-government organisations to make sure that they do follow that agreement. However, I do not believe that we have evidence that once the Government was able to ascertain that there had been breaches it did not take the appropriate action.

One point I would like to take up-it is a point which the Corporation in its response to the Auditor-General's report did not see fit to query and therefore I presume that it accepts it in full-concerns items found on pages 15, 16 and 17 of the Auditor-General's report. They refer to the $25 rebate and the 2 per cent commissions. In the last paragraph on page 15 appears a statement that was not referred to in the Minister's statement, an extraordinary statement to appear in an Auditor-General's report. It is contrary to the report prepared by the ADC and the Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd management dated 2 October 1981 and tabled in the House of Representatives on 29 October 1981, that the $25 per tonne rebate did not replace the 2 per cent commission. In other words, the management of the ADC was prepared to have tabled in the Parliament a document that presumably it knew at the time-certainly it was easily ascertainable by the Attorney-General and not disputed by the ADC-said that the $25 rebate did not replace the 2 per cent commission. The fact of the matter is that while this particular document-an incorrect document-was tabled in the Parliament, at that time the Government did take and had in train sufficient action to prevent any claim being made of a substantive kind against an activity by the Government.

I pursue a second point, on page 17, in relation to the number of errors discovered in the shipping records and the approvals for pricing and concessional adjustments made particularly in relation to skim milk. The fact that these operations could have occurred-a $25 per tonne rebate being paid twice and a 2 per cent commission being paid as well as the rebate; a 2 per cent commission being calculated incorrectly on the credit note; interest credit being given without apparent justification; approval for the free on board reduction credit not being located, an incorrect calculation of an interest rebate and insurance and shipping credits being made without justification, all of which total $246,000-suggests that though there may not have been and does not seem to have been, at least in the judgment of the Solicitor-General, prosecutable activity, there certainly does seem to have been gross negligence and maladministration within those various corporations. This is not new and had been suggested in the Senate Committee report.

It seems to me that there is still sufficient within this whole affair to suggest that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations should continue its investigations and not accede to the Minister's request at the end of his statement which reads:
Let me say that I believe we are approaching an end of a prolonged period of searching examinations of the operations of ADC and ADI.

I believe that that searching examination of the operations should not come to an end, not only because in this matter there is still a range of unanswered questions but also because the Government, presumably, having found such gross administration occurring, would not want at any stage to give up a close scrutiny of the operations of such a corporation until it is satisfied, over a period, that the corporation has in train sufficient safeguards so as to prevent any further occurrence.

Surely, in view of the vast amount of time, energy and effort that the Government, the Senate, the Auditor-General and other government bodies have spent on this matter alone-for which I would imagine that the cost would probably exceed the original amount in question-the only justification for such an enormous expenditure of effort must be that this will not occur in future. The justification does not lie in scoring political points one way or another, but only in that future years the operation of the Corporation, in all its dealings, will accord with the treaties signed by the Government and its international obligations and will accord with all the practices of accounting procedures which are required by the Commonwealth. It is only then, after the passing of a number of years, that the Australian Democrats would believe that one could then say: 'We do not need now a continuing searching examination of the operations of the ADC and can allow it to revert to the normal surveillance that the Government has over any corporations established under Acts of this Parliament or any independent commercial operations'.

I do not believe at this stage that there would be sufficient bona fides on the part of the Corporation to allow it to escape a most rigorous and continuing searching examination of all of its reports, accounts and operations. The type of work done by the Asia Dairy Corporation, an incorporated body arising out of the Australian Dairy Corporation, would also need continual surveillance, and we would hope that the work to which Senator Tate alluded is being done in the way that we believe all government operations should be conducted. Whether or not they succeeded in breaking the law only in other countries is beside the point. No corporations of this Government, of this country, should in any way in their overseas dealings breach any of the laws of overseas countries. The standard of propriety that we require of all companies operating in Australia we should also require of all companies that have government connections, at least in their overseas dealings.

We believe that continuing surveillance by the Senate Standing Committee is useful. It is an operation which it has already in train. It is at present only in suspension. I believe-seemingly the Government has also welcomed this-that that surveillance should continue. The work that the Government has done, certainly from my reading of all these documents, would not suggest that in this matter the Government has been tardy but that it has on every occasion acted as rapidly as one could expect. Because of that, there is no hint, in this matter at least, of ministerial impropriety or lack of ministerial responsibility. If, in relation to other issues, which I am sure we shall be discussing shortly in this chamber, the Minister concerned had not been as rapid in his movements and as conscientious in his undertakings, I believe that the types of reports which have come down in the other place today would not have been able to be written. We would therefore support the Labor Party amendment to allow continuing surveillance of the operations of the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Asian subsidiaries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the amendment moved by Senator Walsh is rather superfluous. Obviously Senator Walsh has been pretty busy and has not been attending the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for the last week or so. I have here a Press release that was issued by the Chairman of that Committee. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry, the Hon. P. J. Nixon, today made a comprehensive and most interesting response, on behalf of the Government, to the matters raised in the Committee's report on the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Asian subsidiaries.
The next sentence is most important:
The Committee will consider the matters raised in the Minister's response and the other documents tabled and report to the Senate in due course.
The chamber should know that it was the Committee's intention in any case to look into all the relevant documents.

Like my colleague Senator Archer, I shall not go over all the ground that has been covered by previous speakers. I should like to bring out just three major points. I bring these out because I think that they help to set the stage for what has happened, and I mention them in no way excusing what has happened. There have been breaches. I do not think that the situation ever reached the stage of what has been indicated-corruption, scandal and the rest-but there have been breaches which should not have happened. However, looking at the stage at that time may help us to understand the situation better.

The dairy industry has never been a wealthy industry. I speak on that from personal experience. It has almost been the peasant farmer class of Australian rural industries, until recent times when the situation has not been too bad. I took out the figures very quickly. At that stage, in 1973-74, we had a stockpile of about 98,000 tonnes of dried skim milk powder. We were not able to get rid of it. We had too many dairy farmers in the industry. In Queensland alone, I think, from that time until just recent times, we literally reconstructed about 22,000 farmers out of the industry-in other words, we reduced it from about 25,000 farmers to about 2,000 to 3,000 farmers today. So as an industry, it was not in a very healthy state. It had a stockpile of skim milk powder that it could not get rid of. That must be pointed out as background to the situation in which the Australian Dairy Corporation found itself.

We then had a chance of markets in South East Asia, and therein lay the problems. We have our own standards of dealing in Australia, but we must find it well nigh impossible to impose those standards when dealing with other countries which have different standards-and no more so than when dealing with countries in South East Asia. They have different standards. There is no doubt about that. The Australian Dairy Corporation had the problem of a stockpile of dried milk to sell, it had possible markets, and it had conflicting methods of dealing. So it went into South East Asia and tried not only to meet the market but to meet the market requirements that exist in that area.

It has been mentioned that money has been siphoned off. Talking with people, as I have in times past, I discovered that it is generally accepted that if one does not have an agent in South East Asia one does not have much chance of doing too many deals. Therefore, one has agents and agents' fees. Usually the agents have an overseas bank account, whether it be in Singapore, Switzerland or wherever. I am not condoning this practice. I am just saying that it is a way of life when dealing with those countries. If Australian industry wants to deal with them it has to meet those requirements. It is relatively easy for private enterprise to do that. Unfortunately, in this case we are dealing with a statutory corporation of this Government. Here is the dilemma: How are such statutory authorities to deal with and look after the people whom they represent and meet the market situation and at the same time meet all the requirements that are laid down by the Government and the requirements of the Auditor-General ? It is now history that they were not able to do that successfully.

I hope that when the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations looks at these documents it will also address itself to this problem: How can bodies, such as the Dairy Corporation, make deals, trade successfully and market Australian products in South East Asian countries, or for that matter , any other country which has ethics different from those which exist in Australia, and at the same time meet the requirements as laid down by the Government and as supervised by the Auditor-General? I believe that is the dilemma of the situation. That is something which has to be addressed rather quickly so that we can meet these markets and look after our suppliers. I hope that the Senate Standing Committee addresses itself to that problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of my duties in the Senate as Deputy President and Chairman of Committees the opportunity does not present itself to me as often as I would like to take part in debates in the Senate. Because I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations which inquired into the Australian Dairy Corporation and Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd and because I was a signatory to the Committee's report I feel that I have an obligation to the members of the Committee and, more importantly, an obligation to my party to express one or two comments on the response of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) to that report. Incidentally, the report was tabled in the Senate as long ago as 17 September 1981, which is over 12 months ago. There can be no question from the Minister's response which was brought down in the House of Representatives last week and which was repeated in the Senate this afternoon that the Government regards the Senate Standing Committee's report as being a most excellent one. That is shown by the degree of attention that has had to be given to it by the Executive and the Department of Primary Industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Having made that comment, let me say that the Parliament has to reassert its supremacy over the Executive and the bureaucracy. I believe the way in which the Senate and, with more particularity, the Senate Standing Committee have been treated by the Government and the bureaucracy has been rather tardy to say the least. I will give one or two instances of that from the documents which have been tabled. The Government seems to have waffled around believing in the old adage that time heals all wounds. The Government hopes that that adage will continue to apply in circumstances of this nature. It is important to remember the rule brought in by this Government itself, probably at the request or instigation of back benchers of the Government parties who were expressing concern at the lackadaisical way in which the Government responded to Senate committee reports. I think it was in 1976 or 1977-early in the life of this Government-that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in another place and the then Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Withers, brought down a report in response to general Senate committee reports saying that in future the Government would respond to a Senate committee report within six months of the report having been presented to the Parliament and that, if the six months period expired during a parliamentary recess, the Government would bring down a report on the very first day of the next sessional sitting. I remind the Senate that this report was tabled on 17 September 1981. Had the Government lived up to its word, it would have reported to the Senate on 17 March 1982. It is now 21 September 1982, some eight or nine months after the time that the Government should have acted according to the condition the Government imposed on itself. Nonetheless, the Government left many of the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee up in the air.

This Parliament has to reassert its supremacy over the Executive and the bureaucracy. The Parliament has to insist that much more efficient and complete response comes from the government of the day to committee reports. I remind the Senate that when this report was first presented members of the Executive, members of the Government, bagged its contents. For instance, I remember the present Vice-President of the Executive Council (Sir James Killen) saying in another place that because all members of the Senate Standing Committee were not present at all sittings of the Committee no one could regard the Committee's report with all seriousness. I pointed out that as there is a quorum for the Senate and the House of Representatives so too there is a quorum for Senate standing committees. In response to that matter, when the debate on the report took place in this chamber on 23 September 1981, as recorded at page 915 of the Senate Hansard, I said:

The Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair)-the former Minister for Primary Industry-instead of accepting the report as a constructive criticism of what has become a sleeping system about which no one seems to care has, as it were, shot from the hip. Ministers have been tolerating the lack of accountability to the Australian public, through the Australian Parliament, by departments and statutory corporations for far too long. That, in short, is the gravamen of the Committee's report and the recommendations contained in it. I suggest that that situation has been occurring because some Ministers have been in office too long . They operate under the 'born to rule' syndrome. They have become far removed from their base, namely their constituencies and the parliamentary system. They act as though they are bricks which are mortared into the wall of bureaucracy. Departments seem to regard their Ministers as the Godfather.

It is now 12 months later, in all fairness to this Parliament and to the Senate, that I must repeat those words. We must remember that there is a representative of the Department of Primary Industry on the Board of the Australian Dairy Corporation. He is there for the purpose of representing the Australian Government. He has been on that Board for a long time. It was his responsibility to report to the the Australian Government. But it is now 12 months after the Committee's report was tabled in the Parliament and the Government is now saying that it is to give further consideration to certain aspects. I refer the Senate to page 189, paragraph 11.9 of the Committee's report, where it said:
When the ADC was created on 1 July 1975, a DPI officer was appointed to the ADC Board under Section 5 (1) (e) of the Dairy Produce Act 1924 to 'represent the Australian Government'.
I repeat those words 'to represent the Australian Government'. The Committee continues:
The first appointment was Mr J. F. O'Bryan who was replaced in August 1979 by the current DPI member, Mr A. E. Wallace.
In reaching its conclusions in that section of the report, at page 211 the Committee states:
As a result of examining the role of the DPI in relation to the ADPB-
that is, the Australian Dairy Produce Board-
and, more particularly, the ADC, the Committee has come to two basic conclusions .

First, we consider that the DPI representatives on the ADC Board have not adequately fulfilled the functions which they themselves have said are required of them and which are quoted in paragraph 11.9. For example, the DPI representatives have not ensured that Government policies have been observed, particularly in relation to the GATT breach, and have not reported adequately on the Asian subsidiaries.
The Committee continues:

Secondly, we believe that the performance of the functions outlined in paragraph 11.9 places DPI officers, as members of the Executive Government, in continual conflict with their role as members of the Board of a statutory authority, the ADC. The separate and distinct duties of a member of a Government department and an independent authority have been constantly blurred. We therefore consider that the following steps are necessary to redefine and clarify the relationship between the DPI and the ADC-
(a) an examination of the practice of the selection of a DPI officer to be a full member of the ADC Board
Reference is then made to chapter 13 of the report for more detail-
(b) the improvement of the system of communicating Government policy to the ADC .

On those two matters which are of extreme importance to the effectiveness of the Government's consideration of the Committee's response, what did the Minister say on Thursday, 12 months after the report was tabled? He said, on the question of general guidelines for statutory authorities:

As honourable members know, the Senate Committee's report raises many general issues of principle such as ministerial control of statutory authorities, including powers of direction; the development of suitable guidelines for the establishment, operation and accountability of statutory authorities and subsidiary companies; the duties and responsibilities of members of such authorities and companies; and reporting requirements. I said in my earlier statement that these general issues of principle were under consideration by an interdepartmental committee and I thought that the Government should be in a position to comment on them by the time I again reported to the Parliament. This task, however, has not yet been completed. When it is a statement will be made by the Government.
The Minister first made his comments on that matter in October of last year when he said:
I thought that the Government should be in a position to comment on them by the time I again reported to the Parliament.

It is now 11 months since the Minister first made his response and on those two important matters, Government representation or no Government respresentation and departmental involvement with a statutory authority, we are still awaiting the Government's determination and a statement from the Government on that matter. At page 1581 of the House of Representatives Hansard of last Thursday, 16 September 1981, the Minister stated:

The Auditor-General's report disclosed deficiencies in the management and operations of ADI and its dealings with the ADC. The ADC established a special management committee to examine all aspects of the Auditor-General's report dealing with managerial and accounting practices of ADI.
I mention this to show how tardy the Government and the bureaucracy have been in the consideration of these matters. The Minister continued:
When the ADC reported to me on 26 October 1979 I--
That is the Minister, nearly three years ago--
concluded that action was immediately required to overcome deficiencies.
That was three years ago and in the House of Representatives only last Thursday he stated:
In my statement of 29 October 1981 I provided detailed information on the action that had been taken.
Even though he wanted immediate action in October 1979, he continued:
On some matters action was incomplete at that time and I have now indicated what further work has been done on these matters.

Frankly it is not good enough. The Government is not fair dinkum. The bureaucracy is too slow and incompetent, probably because of the staff ceilings imposed on the Public Service by the Government. The Public Service is far too slow and it has to be made able and competent to adjust itself to meet the requirements of the Parliament. Is it any wonder, when we are getting reports like the report on the Australian Dairy Corporation, the report of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry, the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, that the Prime Minister has to announce today that there has to be a serious review of the whole Public Service structure in this country?

Having cursorily read the Minister's reponse I say that there are still many questions left up in the air and many matters awaiting resolution by the Government and certainly determination by the Parliament. I have already mentioned the lack of guidelines being laid down by the Government for statutory authorities. I have already mentioned the concern about the general overall question of Government representation on these statutory authorities. There is also the general overall question of ministerial responsibility. The question of where the Department stands in relation not only to this statutory authority but also to others appears to remain unanswered. If one reads the general conclusions that the Government has reached, one must come to the conclusion that basically the Senate Committee's recommendations have been accepted, or should I say understood, but the Government of the day does not know how to respond effectively to or to implement the recommendations of the Committee without necessarily impaling a Minister on a stake.

There is a great problem-it is highlighted by the Government's response-in the present committee system in that departmental officers come before a Senate committee; they give evidence to that committee; the committee presents its report to the Parliament; the report of the committee goes back to the Minister; the Minister sends it on to the Department and, generally speaking, the very departmental officers who have given evidence to that Senate committee consider and study the report of the committee and then are called upon to give advice to the Minister. I believe it is apt for the Senate Standing Committee to study closely the Minister's reply and the documents attached to the Minister's reply. I believe that, in the interests of parliamentary democracy and in the interests of the effectiveness of the Senate committee system, the amendment that has been moved by Senator Walsh should be supported. I therefore have pleasure in supporting the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Walsh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the statement put down earlier this afternoon by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and the amendment moved by my colleague, Senator Walsh, I say at the outset that anything that is said from this side of the House is not intended to discredit the dairy industry, as has been implied by Government senators. What we are about is to highlight the lack of intelligence and integrity of the two Ministers involved-in fact, the whole Government. We were chided by Senator Collard. He said that he alone knew all of the problems of the dairy industry and that he had had some experience in it. Honourable senators on this side too have had personal experience with the dairy industry. My colleague, Senator Primmer, who is from Victoria, was a dairy farmer before he became a member of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: We have never criticised the industry as such. When we were in government between 1972 and 1975 we had a very capable Minister for Primary Industry, the then Senator Ken Wriedt. I am sure that everyone in the industry would agree that Senator Wriedt set about trying to repair all the damage that had been done to the dairy industry over 23 years of Liberal-Country Party government. It was under our jurisdiction that an attempt was made to rationalise the dairy industry and to do something to assist the people engaged in it.

The coalition had a sorry record in government before 1972 and it has had an even sorrier record since it came to office in 1975. If that were not so we would not have had to go through the trauma of all the inquiries which have been conducted. We would not have had to read the very scathing remarks that have been made about the Ministers concerned by the Auditor-General in his reports and to some extent the scathing remarks that have been made in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations about the activities of Ministers. Whilst we hear honourable senators on the other side trying to sweep the whole issue under the carpet and not deal with the real issue which is before us today, I remind the Senate of a speech made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on 12 March 1978 in his electoral talk. He said:
One of my Government's first promises when we were elected just over two years ago was to restore the integrity and honesty in government.

How hollow were those words in the light of what we have witnessed in the last few weeks. Where is the integrity and honesty of this Government now? Even last weekend the very Minister who is under challenge in this statement was getting all the protection he could get from the Prime Minister, just because he is a member of the National Country Party. I have yet to see the Prime Minister give the same sort of protection to Ministers of his own party. I recall what happened to Senator Withers, Mr Moore and Mr MacKellar. Were they given the protection that these 'Nats' are getting? Of course they were not. That is the question which exercises the minds of people in the electorate. Why does the Prime Minister kowtow to the Country Party? What pressure does it use on him to gain his support, in defiance of what members of his own party say, when he ought to take remedial steps? Is the Government so bereft of talent that it cannot do without these people, that these people have to be in government?

I will say something about the Country Party's association with people in the community, one of whom is now behind bars in Long Bay. He was a great friend of the Country Party and was appointed to the bicentennial celebration board to look after the 1988 celebrations. He is now languishing in Long Bay. However, the Prime Minister, in the second paragraph of his statement, went on to say:
Without integrity, without the appearance and reality of integrity no government can hope to have the confidence of the people, or the trust of the people.

What has happened in the last 12 or 18 months has come home to roost because the Government does not have the confidence or the trust of the people. The sooner we have an election the sooner the Government will realise that. The Prime Minister went on to say:

We were determined to restore Australians' faith in their national government- and in the process of government. From the beginning, the government desired to reestablish the absolute propriety and unquestioned integrity that were a hallmark of the Menzies years in Australia.

The Prime Minister has to go back to the Menzies years to find some integrity. When we think about our involvement in Vietnam and the papers tabled in the Parliament by an ex-Liberal Prime Minister, Mr McMahon, some of us would doubt even that statement. They blew the integrity of Menzies out through the roof. He misled the Parliament by saying that he had been invited by the United States of America to participate in Vietnam. Mr McMahon blew his cover when he proved that Menzies had written to the United States President asking that he write to him and request that Australia send troops to Vietnam. Where is the integrity of the Liberal Party? We can go back through history. It has always been able to shove things under the carpet when the pressure comes on. It is impossible for the Government to shove under the carpet and cover up what is before the Parliament and the people of Australia now because these reports cannot be ignored.

We should look back to the Government's behaviour when it was in opposition and to what it accused the Whitlam Labor Government of. I have a whole sheaf of extracts from Hansard of statements made by the present Leader of the Government in this chamber (Senator Sir John Carrick) when he was in opposition. He castigated the Labor Government, accused it of not being honest and of not consisting of people who had integrity. I quote a few of those remarks. I refer to page 1315 of Senate Hansard of 13 May 1975, when the present Government was in opposition and moved a censure motion against Senator Willessee, the then Minister for Foreign Affairs. It is a pity that the Government does not apply these principles today. Senator Carrick stated:

In any other parliament of the Westminster system a Minister who had knowingly misled the parliament would have taken the appropriate action without the need for censure by the parliament. He would have resigned because, quite clearly, knowingly to mislead a parliament and a people is the gravest possible breach of the Westminster principle, and this Minister stands convicted of that.

The Minister who is under question in the statement today tendered his resignation over the weekend. What is the outcome? Today the Prime Minister refused to accept it. That is the complete opposite of what Senator Carrick said in Parliament on 13 May 1975. The Government changes its clothes to suit the purpose. It is not consistent. On 22 October 1975 Senator Carrick, speaking on the Appropriation Bills, said:
One thing that is absolutely clear is that the Prime Minister of Australia has consistently over the months misled the people of Australia and has been guilty of the most reprehensible behaviour.

I quote those words to him because that is the very thing that is happening at the present time with this Government, in particular the Prime Minister and the two Ministers involved in this inquiry. We could go further, as we will in debates later in this Parliament, and talk about the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). However, on 30 October 1975 Senator Carrick went on to say:

Day by day more and more information comes out, not only about the most massive economic chaos and mismanagement that anybody has seen in Australia since Federation but also about dishonesty, deception and even corruption in government. This Government admits to no principles at all. It admits to no precedents in the way that it governs.

That is what Senator Carrick said about the Whitlam Government. It is very appropriate to use that quote against the Fraser Government and the Ministers whom it consistently tries to protect. As my colleague Senator McClelland, mentioned a while ago, the wire service today states:
Prime Minister Mr Malcolm Fraser today foreshadowed a major review of the Public Service in the wake of the Woodward and Costigan Royal Commission reports .

No doubt those comments would also apply to the reports that have come before this Parliament on Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd. It is quite obvious that the Government is running scared, as the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) used to say about the Labor Party. Who is running scared today? It is the Fraser Liberal-National Country Party Government. It has quite a few of its Ministers under challenge. I dare say that, as has been reported in some newspapers, the Government will endeavour to tough it out and hope that the matter can be swept under the carpet. However, I assure honourable senators that that is not going to happen. I thought that my colleague the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, when speaking to the statement in the other place last Thursday, used a very appropriate quotation. He said: 'The GATT is out of the bag'. Of course what he meant was that the cat was out of the bag. It is out of the bag all right, due to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. It is out of the bag, due also to the report of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry, which was tabled today in another place and which will be tabled here later. In fact, the Government has many skeletons in the cupboard. Despite what the three Government speakers said when they were trying to distance themselves from the operations of their ministerial colleagues, they were unsuccessful. When people read Hansard and see the waffle they went on with, which was quite divorced from the problems with which we are now faced, they will realise that what they were attempting was a very weak excuse for Mr Nixon and his predecessor, Mr Sinclair.
Last Thursday my colleague in the other place also drew attention to several facts. He said:
The previous Minister--
He was talking about Mr Sinclair--

would not give evidence to the Senate Committee, he would not answer questions and he would not table his records. The Government at that time would not table the Auditor-General's report. It was duck-shoving, pigeon-holing and delaying a police report. That report still has not seen the light of day. We still do not know what was in that. That is why the allegations will continue about whether the situation was covered up by people responsible in this Government or by others. That has been the problem.
I join my colleague, Mr Kerin, in asking that that police report be made available.

This Government has a long history of claiming that interdepartmental reports and consultants reports-and consultants reports are paid for by the taxpayer-are confidential. I complain continually about that in this chamber and at Estimates Committee hearings. We have the Marks report and another consultant's report which was carried out at Mr Marks's recommendation at the cost of about $50,000. Most of these consultants reports are carried out at a cost to the taxpayer and yet it is claimed that they are confidential and the Parliament cannot have a look at them. Last week, during the hearing of Estimates Committee C, I asked the Auditor-General what was the cost to the Auditor-General's Department of the Asia Dairy Industries inquiry. The answer I received is dated 14 September. it is signed by Mr K. F. Brigden, Auditor-General, and states:
The inquiry into Asia Dairy Industries has cost the Office $40,016 as at 9 September 1982.

That is what this inquiry has cost the taxpayer, through the Auditor-General's Office. But what has it really cost the taxpayer? If we could get the figures that show the total amount it would be an enormous amount of money. That cost has been brought about purely because of the laxity of both the Ministers in question, Mr Sinclair and Mr Nixon, in not carrying out the job they are paid to do, in not being vigilant enough as Ministers. I join my colleagues in saying that they should not be Ministers. This Government, of course, has gone through so many people in the ministerial ranks that it has very few left to pick from. No wonder people outside are saying that it is time we had an election and got some new blood to run the country. What we are saying is not fictitious. The proof is there in the documents which are tabled in the Parliament relating to inquiries that have been held right along the line. We can go to the Costigan report, the report with which we are dealing, and many others. Every one of them , somewhere along the line, points to the mismanagement of the country's affairs by this Liberal-National Country Party Government. People will now ask--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, the police reports were tabled. The police reports dated 24 October 1980 and 24 September 1981 were tabled on 29 October 1981.
—I doubt, Minister, whether they are the police reports to which Mr Kerin was referring.
—I am advised that they are.

—I accept the answer and if I am wrong in what I have said, if I have made a false accusation, I apologise to anyone I may have offended. I will search out those reports and see whether they are the ones I am talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Scott, when he was speaking today, said that in the area which we are discussing a great deal of investigation has been necessary. Of course we know it has, and it has been at great cost. I say to Senator Scott that he would know that had his own party colleagues, namely, Mr Sinclair and Mr Nixon, as the responsible Ministers, acted in a more vigilant manner, this whole sorry saga may not have occurred. If these Ministers had been doing their job we might not be in the position we are in today, debating the statement made by the Minister, and the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations may not have had to waste a lot of its time. But as it turned out, the Committee was not wasting its time because a lot of useful information has come to light. Indeed, if it had not been for the persistence of Senator Walsh in raising this matter after certain documents came into his possession, many of the matters which have been examined by the Auditor-General, at the cost of $40,000 which I have mentioned, and by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, would not have seen the light of day. Senator Walsh came in for some very unkind criticism from the Government when he first raised this issue. It is to his credit that the criticism did not deter him but in fact made him more determined to ensure that the issue was not swept under the carpet as the Prime Minister and his two Ministers who were involved would have liked it to be, and no doubt as the three Government members who have spoken on this matter today would have liked it to be. But that is not to be.
My colleague Senator Douglas McClelland quoted a couple of paragraphs of the statement put down by the Minister. I also will quote from the statement. Mr Nixon said:

I said in my earlier statement that these general issues of principle were under consideration by an inter-departmental Committee, and I thought that the Government should be in a position to comment on them by the time I again reported to the Parliament. This task, however, has not been completed. When it is, a statement will be made by the Government.

My colleague Senator Douglas McClelland dealt at some length with the matter of these reports being tabled in the Parliament. I think it goes without saying that under the policy of this Government no one on this side of the House, anyway, will see the interdepartmental report. Some statement will be made about it and what arises out of it but we will not see it. At page 14 of the document, Mr Nixon said:
The borrowing and investment guidelines for ADI will be finalised when the Government has decided on the guidelines to apply to Statutory Authorities generally.

How long will we have to wait until those guidelines are made public? If it is like some of the other things we are waiting for, it will be for ever and a day. We will never see them. But of course it is not only the members of the Opposition who are making criticisims against this Government for its action. If we look at a letter signed by the First Assistant Auditor-General, Mr Monaghan, addressed to Mr Enfield, the Deputy Secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, and dated 10 August 1982, we see that in the fourth paragraph of that letter Mr Monaghan said:

There is only one other comment that we would make. Many of the observations by the Corporation relate to details of little, if any consequence, but we note that the report has generated a remarkable resurgence of memory on the part of officers of the Corporation who, during the audit investigation, found themselves unable to offer more than the barest modicum of information to the audit team.

As the inquiry proceeded, their memory came back, and they were able to say certain things. Had the Ministers been vigilant when this matter was first raised many years ago, they would have put a fine tooth comb through the Department and found out what was going on. But they did not see fit to do that. I guess they regret it today, and they will regret it even more as the months go by. But that is what they should have done because no matter what happens in a department, Ministers should not blame their departmental officers. That is what is happening with this Government now. It is under challenge. I think it was only this morning or perhaps last night that I saw on a television show that Mr Gee has come under some criticism because of the report of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry which has been brought down. No doubt many other departmental officers are being blamed and being made the scapegoats by this Government because of the lack of vigilance by Ministers.

Ministers cannot, just the same as back bench members of parliament cannot-and back benchers are only small fish in the pond-blame their staff. If one of our staff gives misleading information to a constituent, quite innocently and not deliberately, it is the member of parliament who must bear the brunt of it. We are responsible for our staff and Ministers should be responsible for anything that goes on in their departments and not try to lay the blame on departmental officers. We all know that departmental officers are there to serve the government of the day. I would say that on most occasions none of those officers would set out deliberately to mislead a Minister. But if the Minister is lackadaisical and not attending to his work as he should be, he should not be in the ministry. But at no time should he be prepared, when he is in trouble, as these Ministers are, to blame his departmental officers. We have seen not only Mr Nixon but also the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), now that they are under severe questioning, trying to lay the blame on their departmental heads or people who work in the department.

That is not good enough. That will not happen when we get back into government and that will occur before very long. Our Ministers will see that departments are run the way they ought to be. If anything goes wrong our Ministers can expect to get the chop, as they did when we were in government between 1972 and 1975. That is what this Government ought to be doing. Instead of allowing Ministers to level all the criticism for their failings at their departmental officers, the Cabinet, under the Prime Minister, should be sacking them. Of course, this sort of behaviour cannot happen under Australian Labor Party rules because all members of our Ministry are elected by all members of the parliamentary Labor Party. That does not happen under this Government. Every Minister owes his position in the Ministry to the favouritism of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) because Ministers are chosen by him. Back bench members of the Government have no opportunity to make any input. Once they elect their leader the leader then selects the people who are going to offer him the least line of resistance. As I said, fortunately that does not happen in the Labor Party. Labor Ministers would be on their mettle at all times.

One of the most damning indictments of a Minister is contained in an article written in Canberra by Michelle Grattan and Simon Balderstone which appears in today's Melbourne Age. I will not quote all of the article. However, I think some of the failings of the Minister who is under challenge ought to be pointed out. The article states:

Late in 1979, Mr Nixon was landed with another issue, the festering sore of the Asia Dairy Industries affair. The matter had been raised under the Ministership of Mr Nixon's predecessor, Mr Sinclair, but an Auditor-General's report outlining malpractice and financial misconduct within ADI-a wholly owned subsidiary of the Australian Dairy Corporation-was submitted to him shortly after he took over the Primary Industry portfolio in September 1979.
So Mr Nixon has had over three years to look at this and straighten out problems which have occurred. The article continued:
Mr Nixon continually refused to table the report in Parliament, claiming such action was not appropriate at the time, but constant leaking of parts of the report kept the issue bubbling.

Of course, I think we again can give credit to Senator Walsh who had certain information in his possession and was prepared to use it. As I said in my opening remarks, if he had not been so vigilant and persistent this matter would never have seen the light of day. We give great credit to Senator Walsh for that . The article continued:
It boiled over in September last year, when the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations brought down a report on the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Asian subsidiaries.

The article gives details. I will not take up any more time of the Senate because the article is contained in today's Melbourne Age. My colleagues have detailed the whole sorry mess in which this Government has found itself. I think the only way left open to us is to support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Walsh and to let the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations have another look at the whole matter.

I just want to give a final illustration of how this Government tries to cover up what it does. I mentioned earlier in my remarks that Mr Harry M. Miller has many friends in the Government, particularly in the National Country Party. We have debated many times in this Parliament the many things Mr Harry M. Miller has done at the taxpayers' expense. He now finds himself behind the heavy doors of Long Bay gaol. But that is not sufficient for this Government. Three daily papers-I think the Sydney Morning Herald, the Australian, and the Melbourne Age of 6 July this year-reported that the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) paid a visit to Long Bay to see Mr Harry M. Miller. According to reports, when the Deputy Prime Minister was asked about the meeting he said that the visit was arranged by Miller's wife, Wendy. Mr Anthony was quoted in the Age as saying: 'I was hoping no one would know about it'. So that is the way in which this Government acts. The Government was hoping that no one would know about the problems in respect of Asia Dairy Industries and it was hoping that no one would know about the meat scandal-and we have to give another Labor member, Senator Primmer, full credit for revealing that. Senator Primmer too was ridiculed in this Parliament when he first raised this matter in 1978. I say to the Government that we on this side of the Senate are vigilant in Opposition. We will pursue these matters to see that justice is done and when we are in government we will ensure that our Ministers oversee their departments in the way that Ministers should as servants of the electors. I support the amendment moved by Senator Walsh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is properly exercising a review of the various reports that have been available to us in recent times about the activities of the Department of Primary Industry and one of its statutory authorities, the Australian Dairy Corporation. I think I should remind the Senate that this is the fifth scandal to hit the Government in a Budget session that is now in its sixth week. I refer, of course, to the difficulties the Government is in in respect of deficiencies in the Attorney-General's Department and the statement made by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) about the deficiencies that exist in the Australian Taxation Office, both of which relate to massive tax evasion and tax avoidance costing the Government hundreds of millions of dollars in forgone tax revenue. We also see unfolding the fraud by doctors in respect of Medibank fraud which is substantiated by the Australian Medical Association itself.

SPEECH.PARA: The House of Representatives today is debating the deficiencies in the administration of the meat industry-the meat substitution scandal. We in the Senate are talking about problems associated with the dairy industry and surplus supplies of skim milk that in some way or other were sold illegally on foreign markets. So the Parliament should be concerned about the great drop in public morality and ministerial propriety. I understand that the Government has reluctantly decided to support Senator Walsh's amendment to send this matter back to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for another analysis and examination of the activities of the Department of Primary Industry and the Australian Dairy Corporation.

We are discussing activities on a massive scale, involving illegalities and irregularities and breaches of proper business practice, which have affected, and will continue to affect, the trading reputation of Australia. We have been shown conclusively that there have been breaches of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, commonly known as GATT, in respect of our surplus products. Also, in the debate that currently is taking place in the other House, it has been shown that we have been breaching trading proprieties in respect of our meat.

We are aware that there was a substantial surplus of skim milk powder in 1975- 76. It is not satisfactory for the Government to say in 1982, some six or seven years later, that it did not concern itself as to the means and the processes by which those surplus products were disposed of. This matter was drawn to the attention of the Government and to the Opposition. Senator McLaren will recall that in 1976, when I was the Labor Party spokesman on agricultural matters, Mr Webster came before our party committee with the permission of the then Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Sinclair, to talk to us about surplus supplies of skim milk powder. I would have to be a fool not to recognise that if that information was available to the Opposition it was available to the Government. Are honourable senators opposite seriously contesting the view that Mr Sinclair did not seek, in any way, shape or form, to find out how those surplus stocks were being sold? He must have known, and did know, that steps were taken to dispose of them in years past in a way which can only be described as very unsatisfactory from the point of view of the Australian Government and the Australian nation. I remind the Senate of what the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations said. I refer to paragraph 9.38 of its report. The Committee unanimously stated:

We have weighed up all relevant considerations, having regard to the evidence set out above, the evidence relating to Mr Sinclair's known interest in the GATT breach issue and to the Committee's own assessment of the likely course of events in all the circumstances. The Committee concludes that on the balance of probabilities, Mr Sinclair's recollection of the events was not as reliable as that of Mr Webster. In other words, it appears to the Committee that on the balance of probabilities, Mr Sinclair was told of the terms of the compromise which necessarily involved a continuing breach of GATT.

In the light of that conclusion of the Committee-it was an all-party committee and the Government's representatives on it were in the majority-does the Government still say that Mr Sinclair is not culpable, that Mr Sinclair did not know and that Mr Sinclair is fulfilling his responsibilities as a Minister? It is all right for the Government and for the Prime Minister of the day in the House of Representatives to suggest that some sort of an inquiry will be held into the Public Service because of alleged deficiencies in the Taxation Office which comes within the responsibility of the Treasurer; deficiencies in the Attorney-General's Department as suggested by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union; deficiencies which exist in the Department of Health with respect to taxpayers' money that has been ripped off by avaricious doctors; deficiencies which the Government suggests exist in the Department of Primary Industry so far as the meat issue is concerned; and deficiencies which obviously exist in the Australian Dairy Corporation. Is the Government really saying that all these problems flow solely from maladministration in the Public Service and, therefore, an inquiry should be held into the activities of the Public Service? In other words, the Government is attempting to shift the blame from the Minister to his Department, to the permanent head of his Department and to his immediate advisers. Senator Douglas McClelland and other honourable senators from this side of the House have suggested that.

I reject the suggestion by Senator Macklin-I was surprised to hear him make this suggestion-that in some way or other the Minister was not responsible. I believe the Minister was responsible. I remind the Senate that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations first took up the brief with respect to the Australian Dairy Corporation in 1977. As its first report indicates, it was frustrated by its inability to get information about what was happening with respect to the sales of our skim milk powder surpluses.

In 1977 the Australian Financial Review referred to a rebate system that was operated by the statutory authority and said that it was in fact a breach of our international obligations. In September 1977 the Committee was told, however, that the potential breach had been rectified. Having received that information, the Committee stopped its investigations. It was not until 28 March 1979 that the Auditor-General was called upon to investigate allegations concerning the Australian Dairy Corporation. It was not until August 1980 that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) took the important step of referring the matter to the Australian Federal Police because of his concern. He called for an investigation into that organisation. What does all the evidence show? All the evidence shows that all the documents relating to that period have disappeared. They are missing. What did the Auditor-General say in respect to this matter? At page 5 of the Auditor-General's report it is stated:
The problem was compounded by there being no current ADC or ADI staff member who had a detailed knowledge of the accounting system operating at the time in question.
In a more recent statement dated 10 August 1982 a letter from the Auditor- General's Office stated:

Many of the observations by the Corporation relate to details of little, if any , consequence, but we note that the report has generated a remarkable resurgence of memory on the part of officers of the Corporation who, during the audit investigation, found themselves unable to offer more than the barest modicum of information to the audit team.
The Opposition believes that the public administration leaves a great deal to be desired. In the statement of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) to the Parliament today it is stated:
The Department of Primary Industry also confirmed that the records now available within the ADC are inadequate to identify any trader-to-trader sales that may have breached the GATT agreement.
This statement was made in 1982; yet the breaches took place in 1975-76. The statement continued:

A questionnaire has been sent to all licensed exporters in order to determine what records they have retained in respect of the period concerned. Responses to date indicate that it will be impossible to show whether or not there was any widestread breach of the GATT arrangements.

The Government concedes that there are irregularities but it attempts to say that it is not responsible as a government; the responsibility lies with somebody in the Public Service. We in the Opposition find that a complete abdication of ministerial responsibility. We find that completely unacceptable. The Opposition believes that at best it was slackness and at worst it was incompetence and negligence. A government that has been operating in this sort of fashion surely has lost the confidence of the Parliament and the Australian people. After all, the Parliament has the responsibility in this matter. The Parliament has been attempting to establish what has been going on in this area. It is five years since the Senate's own committee looked at this matter. It is more than a year, as Senator Douglas McClelland pointed out, since the Minister had the report placed in his jurisdiction.

I find it rather unusual, to say the least, that we should be discussing the Australian Dairy Corporation in the Senate on Tuesday, 21 September, a couple of days after the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee in Finance and Government Operations-a Government supporter-has left the country on an overseas trip. His diligence and activity in this area have the support of the Opposition . On all occasions on that Committee we sought to establish the veracity or otherwise of what it is alleged has been going on. Australia's reputation as a major trading nation in this area surely has been damaged seriously by this issue, as it has by the meat substitution issue. The latter is the subject of a report that has been presented to the Parliament today. Our reputation as a major world trading nation has been seriously jeopardised. That report represents an indictment of this Government. After all these years of Senator Peter Rae, as Chairman of this Committee, talking about the problems of our statutory authorities and the irregularities that operate because of the failure of the Government to set clear and concise guidelines, we still have a situation where we do not have a satisfactory response from the Government about the way in which our statutory authorities should be operated. I remind the Senate of what the Standing Committee's report-presented last year as parliamentary paper No. 153 of 1981-said at page 94 of its conclusion on a statutory authority and its subsidiaries:

A statutory authority and its subsidiaries, whose actions have the potential to reflect adversely upon the Australian government, the Parliament and the nation, should not engage in individual arrangements to secure business which necessitate bribery, corruption, tax evasion, artificial schemes whose purposes are tax avoidance and so on.

The report goes on to deal with that in slightly more detail. We are discussing an issue of corruption, bribery and theft because $3m to $4m has disappeared somewhere in the process of this whole arrangement in Singapore. Who has the money? Nobody can say. What has happened to it? Nobody can say. There are no records. There has been such a change in staff and in ministerial arrangements that nobody can give us a satisfactory explanation. One can say only that in looking at that order of corruption, bribery and theft we also have evidence of tax evasion and tax avoidance which is being pursued. I think it is probably being too generous to say that all of this is due to incompetence and negligence .

There has clearly been a conspiracy of some sort involving the statutory authority which is under the control and management of the Department of Primary Industry. At what point does somebody accept responsibility for these matters? Australia will finish up having no reputation whatsoever. Are we going to rely upon pure incompetence in the Department? Are we going to say that the Minister was not negligent in carrying out his responsibility? At what point do we draw that fine line? At what point do we say that the Minister is culpable? At what point do we say that he is negligent or incompetent? This Government has a declining standard of ministerial responsibility. It is no wonder, therefore, that the Auditor-General has made the comments that he has but which we have not time to detail completely. We can say that we have a government that has been besieged with more scandals than any government in Australia's history. We can say that we have a government that defends the failures of Ministers to fulfil their proper responsibilities. We can say that we have a government that now has a litany of incompetent Ministers, all of whom seek to shelter under an umbrella of either ministerial non-knowledge or some failure in the department itself. We are entitled to say, therefore, that the report is not a very satisfactory one at all and that the Government's approach to this matter is not satisfactory. We are entitled to say that we are not impressed with the views of the Crown Solicitor who gave the Government certain advice on these matters. We are also entitled to say that the constant changing of Ministers does have the effect of providing the means by which those Ministers can escape their ministerial responsibilities. The constant changing of Health Ministers and Ministers for Primary Industry contributes to an atmosphere and a pattern of behaviour which is unsatisfactory. That can be sheeted home to no other person than the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) who, after all, in hand picking his own team has to pick lackeys and people who are prepared to do his bidding.

We reject entirely the concept that is now being used by the Prime Minister to suggest that all of this flows from some failure of administration in the Public Service. We reject that because it rejects the concept of ministerial responsibility. I again remind the Senate that the Government is receiving body blow after body blow for its failure properly to account for its activities to the Parliament and to the Australian people in such a wide variety of issues. If it were a decent government based on decent principles it would do nothing less than resign and face the Australian people. I believe the Government is being forced, per force of the debate that has taken place here today, to support the amendment moved by Senator Walsh. It has no alternative. That is clearly shown in the debate. In addition to the Minister for Social Security who presented the report, we have had two 5-minute contributions by two Government senators who set out to try to defend the indefensible in respect of the Australian Dairy Corporation.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO THE AUSTRALIAN MEAT INDUSTRY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry dated September 1982 as well as an extract from the transcript of evidence dated 13 July and 14 July 1982 and a file note dated 19 September 1982 recording a conversation between the Secretary of the Department of Primary Industry and Mr Buettel, a member of the Committee of Inquiry into the Meat Inspection Systems. I seek leave to make a statement in connection with the report, to have the statement incorporated in Hansard, and to move that the Senate take note of the statement and the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I present the report of the Royal Commission into the Australian meat industry. I seek leave to make a statement. In mid-August 1981, discoveries were made in the United States of horse meat having been substituted for beef by an Australian meat export establishment. Immediate steps were taken both in the USA and Australia to retain meat from the establishment concerned. As a result of these discoveries the Minister for Primary Industry took a number of immediate steps to which I shall later refer in more detail. When this substitution became public knowledge in both countries there was a public outcry, particularly in Australia. Allegations of widespread malpractice were made in this Parliament and in Victoria. Despite the immediate effectiveness of the measures taken at that time the Australian meat industry had been severely tarnished.

It was imperative that Australia's international reputation be cleared. The Government believed that the only means by which this could be achieved to the satisfaction of everyone in the community was through the establishment of a Royal Commission of high standing and repute to examine the matter. Letters patent appointing the Honourable Mr Justice Woodward to conduct the Royal Commission were issued by His Excellency the Governor-General on 12 September 1981.
The Commission was charged with inquiring into:

''(a) Whether administrative arrangements and procedures for the supervision of the handling of meat for export are adequate to ensure that all meat exported from Australia meets the requirements prescribed by law;
(b) Whether malpractices are occurring, or have occurred, in the handling of meat for export or the exportation of meat;

(c) Allegations made, whether in public or to a Minister, Department or Authority of the Commonwealth, of malpractices alleged to have occurred during the past ten years, in the handling of meat for export or in the exportation of meat;
(d) Whether such allegations were dealt with in a manner that was adequate and effective;
(e) Whether in response to such allegations, any illegality or corruption occurred.''

As allegations had also been made in relation to malpractices in the Victoria Meat Inspection Service, His Excellency the Governor of Victoria issued, on 15 September 1981, a Royal Commission which complemented the Commonwealth Commission but which related to meat for human consumption in Victoria. In November 1981, the Governor-General issued a further Commission in relation to meat for human consumption in the Northern Territory. Because of the considerable degree of overlap between the three commissions, enquiries in relation to all three were conducted jointly and concurrently. The Commissioner has discharged his three separate obligations by presenting a single Report. However, his concluding recommendations relating to the three separate governmental jurisdictions are set out separately.

The Commission's Report was presented to the Governor-General and the Governor of Victoria and forwarded to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory on 17 September. The Commissioner recommended that Appendix H, which is a separate volume to the Report, not be released until after criminal proceedings against those named or referred to in it have been completed.

At the outset I should say that on a dispassionate reading the findings of the Royal Commission are overwhelmingly positive. The Commission has commended the Department and the Minister in relation to their actions in the wake of the substitution incident. While there was a great deal wrong with the meat inspection system prior to the substitution incident, the Royal Commissioner has found that actions taken since then have been the appropriate ones. He has also endorsed most of the proposals advanced by the Department of Primary Industry for further improving the system. The positive suggestions the Commissioner has made are being and will be followed up vigorously.

Before going into the Royal Commission Report in detail it would be useful for honourable senators if I recalled the total background against which the Royal Commission enquiry was held. The meat industry is one of Australia's vital rural industries. The estimated value of production last year was $3.2 billion-more than a quarter of the gross value of rural production. It is a substantial export earner with exports of $1.3 billion to some 60 overseas markets.

The problem of wasteful dual meat inspection services in the four larger states has bedevilled the industry for many years. Following overseas complaints many years ago, the original Commonwealth Veterinary Service was expanded to an export inspection service in all states. New United States laws in 1963 and 1967 required greater Commonwealth controls. In 1964 some states, concerned at the increased Commonwealth role in meat inspection, sought and obtained agreement that state and Commonwealth inspectors work side by side in export establishments.

Over the years this situation has led to costly duplication and some fragmentation of administrative controls. Between 1972 and 1978 there were no fewer than six major state or Commonwealth enquiries into meat inspection. At all these times the objective of the Commonwealth was to participate in any reasonable arrangements to achieve a single inspection service. However because of the attitude of some states no progress was made in this direction. In November 1978 the then Minister for Primary Industry, in yet another attempt to resolve the issue, established a Committee of Enquiry with terms of reference specifically directed to the solution of problems of meat inspection administration.

I want to address this particular Enquiry in some detail because it was material in relation to an adverse finding by the Royal Commission against the Minister for Primary Industry. The importance of this matter will become clear later in my statement.

The Chairman of this Enquiry, the Hon C. R. Kelly and the other Committee member, Mr W. B. Buettel presented their Report to the Minister for Primary Industry on 11 February 1980. The whole thrust of their Report tabled in Parliament on 27 February 1980 was directed to the establishment of a new type of single meat inspection system, and Australian Meat Inspection Service or '' AMIS''. In the presentation of the Report to the Minister on 11 February 1980 evidence shows that the discussion was centred around the principles and proposed structure of a new AMIS. Mr Kelly also, at this brief meeting, raised the general issue of malpractice in meat inspection as reflected on pages 12, 13 and 66 of his Report.

However, at the time and as indeed evidenced in his Report, these allegations were of a most general nature, and have remained so. Neither in his Report, nor in his meeting with the Minister did Mr Kelly put forward any positive or specific evidence of names of people engaged in serious malpractice. Even at the Royal Commission Mr Kelly was not able to present any specific information and he has not done so since. If he had they would have been passed on to the police for investigation.

Some matters of immediate administrative concern that arose in the Kelly Enquiry were passed on to the Department by Mr Landos, the Departmental executive officer to the Kelly Committee. I have been advised that the Bureau of Animal Health followed up with their field staff, but as later events showed not vigorously enough. The notes taken by Mr Landos during the Enquiry were never referred to Mr Nixon by Mr Landos, or Mr Kelly. Mr Kelly's key recommendation for the establishment of an AMIS was studied but rejected by the states. The Commonwealth was prepared at all times to support AMIS. In further pursuit of an improved system, a Commonwealth/state Committee of the Australian Agricultural Council, set up in 1980 following the Kelly Report, still failed to resolve the issue of a single service.

At a meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council in Hobart in February 1981 the Minister for Primary Industry took yet another initiative to resolve the issue. A high level working group was established to consider further options. Yet again, however, no satisfactory consensus emerged.

It is quite clear that the central pre-occupation and the priorities attached to both the Kelly Report and the Commonwealth consideration of it was the achievement of a single meat inspection service.
This is clear in Mr Kelly's evidence to the Royal Commission and I quote from page 10264 of the transcript:

'We were much more interested in the problems of administration and having inspectors available at the right time and at the right place than we were at that time about the bribery and corruption.
