SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill (No. 2) 1982 is another of those now familiar omnibus Bills. It is bigger and more detailed than even the last one, which we debated on 21 April of this year. This measure has 280 clauses. The last measure had 237. It also has 12 schedules , amending a total of 75 Acts. Last time 39 Acts were involved. Also it affects some 17 ministerial portfolios. Size of that kind is no problem in itself but does make the task of eternal vigilance that much more difficult. We have seen too often important substantive amendments tucked away in such Bills as this. We have seen that too often to enable us to take such a Bill as this simply on trust.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me recite again a little homily on the subject in the hope that repetition will finally produce results. The Opposition requests a number of things in regard to these kinds of Bills; first, that they contain no matters other than those which genuinely deal with tidying up, correction and updating, or routine administrative changes. Only matters of that kind should be included in a miscellaneous amendments Bill. Secondly, we ask that the program of reprinting Commonwealth Acts be speeded up to ensure that these amendments will be more quickly incorporated in parent Acts, which are used by members of the Parliament , the legal profession and the public. Thirdly, we request specifically that no amendments be made therein to the legislation constituting the co-operative companies and securities scheme. This Bill does include some amendments of the Companies Act and the Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act, as did the previous measure, in April.

We take the view that it must be possible for such amendments to be contained in a separate Bill, which would make significantly easier the already enormously difficult task of lawyers, company secretaries and others in the community of trying to keep up with this already inordinately messy companies and securities legislation. Having recited that little homily for the second time in six months , might I now make clear that the Bill is not opposed by the Opposition, which has scrutinised it as it was best able, having in mind that 17 different shadow Ministers must look at their respective parts of it. We have come to the conclusion that it contains no controversial or noisome provisions.

However, I believe one or two matters deserve a quick comment. I refer first to Part XII of the Bill which contains proposed amendments of the Banking Act. As the second reading speech indicates these amendments are designed to facilitate the two bank mergers which were approved by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in 1980-81 , namely that of the Bank of New South Wales and the Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd and that of the National Bank and the Commercial Banking Company of Sydney Ltd. We do not object to these amendments, providing as they do just for administrative simplicity in a whole range of matters where there would otherwise be confusion, delay and consequent complex reorganisation upon the mergers taking effect. Of course, any such confusion or delay would affect employees and customers of the banks. We do not want to see that happening. But we take the opportunity briefly to remind the Parliament and anyone else who might conceivably be interested of the Opposition's serious concern about these mergers, as spelt out in detail by the shadow Treasurer, Mr Willis, in the House of Representatives on 27 May 1981. In particular, we have expressed our concern about the undue concentration of economic power which is a product of these mergers; also, the reduction in competition, the other side of that coin, not only in banking but also in the finance industry as a whole, which flows from what is, after all, a reduction by one-third from six to four, in the number of major trading banks. We have also expressed concern about the possible loss of employment in the industry as a result of the mergers, none of which questions were adequately answered by the Treasurer, then or subsequently.

The second matter, to which I refer briefly, is the Acts Interpretation Act amendments, to be found in Part VI of the Bill. Firstly, there is a revision of the definition of 'department'. It is a small change but one which makes manifest good sense so far as the streamlining of legislation is concerned and the facilitation of administrative rearrangements in existing departments and those that have particular subject matters within their jurisdiction-not that the Opposition necessarily believes that there ought to be quite such a constant parade of administrative arrangements as has been a phenomenon of this Government and, admittedly, the Labor Government of 1972 to 1975. To the extent that it becomes necessary to make those rearrangements from time to time, it is manifestly convenient that legislation not have to be altered to reflect such changes.

More interestingly, perhaps, there are in the context of the Acts Interpretation Act amendments to a number of specific Acts to bring them into line with sections 48 to 50 of the Acts Interpretation Act. This involves the continuing process of implementing the 1981 recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances relating to the treatment of subordinate legislation and the application of disallowance procedures on a uniform basis. This progressive bringing into line of other legislation with these desirable procedural changes in an entirely legitimate function to be accomplished by an Act of this kind and we record our satisfaction at seeing it incorporated in this Bill.

As to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act, which is also the subject of some attention, we simply reiterate the point that we have made on a number of occasions-that we do not want ever our assent to changes to that legislation to be taken as in any way representing a resiling by the Opposition from what remains our implacable opposition to the so-called off-shore settlement and to the abdication of Commonwealth sovereignty over coastal waters and the seabed which was involved in that settlement. That is a position which I, for one, spelt out in the Senate on 27 May 1982. Perhaps it is desirable to reiterate it now.

I wish to comment on one final matter. It is not about something which is in the Bill but about something which is not in the Bill-an amendment to reinstate all or part of section 85E of the Crimes Act which was repealed by the Crimes Amendment Act. The details of this matter are not important and do not need to be retailed here because they were raised in the hearings of Estimates Committee A last Monday, 13 September as recorded at page 285 of the Hansard. What was involved here was the apparently inadvertent repeal of some quite convenient provisions in the Crimes Act, making it possible for matter arising in one State to be dealt with by court procedures in another. On the evidence available to me it has certainly caused a lot of inconvenience to the prosecution and to the defence in a number of matters. Perhaps not in every matter has that been the case and there may be some balancing out to be done but there is obviously a case for at least making possible by consent the hearing and determination of matters in another State from that in which they arose. It is to be hoped that this correction to the legislation will be quickly reaccomplished.

The particular point I make in this context is that that is the kind of measure that would have been appropriate to put into again a miscellaneous amendments Bill of this kind and it does appear that as a result of some dilatoriness on the part of the Attorney-General's Department the bus was missed on this occasion and will not be caught again until something like April next year when the next round of miscellaneous amendments is with us. That is an unhappy state of affairs and one that demands some comment. Whether it justifies the Commonwealth trying to bring in a separate Crimes Amendment Bill is something I do not pursue at this stage but if it appears that the inconvenience of this legislation is mounting then perhaps that course will be necessary.

It is not necessary or desirable to say anything more in the context of this Bill, being the rag bag that it is, except to reiterate with some strength of feeling, for the benefit at least of those officers present if not for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), the points I was making about the proper content of this kind of legislation. The Opposition does not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise three matters in relation to the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill (No. 2). I acknowledge that it is a Bill which is essentially of an omnibus type. I make an appeal to the Government or to the draftsmen of this type of legislation that when so many amendments are required perhaps we could be given a page reference. That would certainly have expedited the location of a number of the matters under consideration today.

SPEECH.PARA: Recognising that this Bill is an omnibus Bill of a non-controversial nature, I want to introduce a matter of minor conjecture in relation to the Audit Act. I refer to page 2 of the explanatory notes which accompany the Bill. Section 82B of the Audit Act 1901 restricts the investment of moneys standing to the credit of the trust fund maintained under Part IX of the Act to Commonwealth and State securities, deposits in a bank and the purchase of coinage. Part VII of the Bill amends section 62B of the Act so as to provide wider avenues of investment of such moneys. That is the emphasis I wish to make and to speak about tonight. The amendments will permit investment in securities issued by the Commonwealth Government on loans to authorised dealers in the official money market in certificates of deposit and in clean bills of exchange. Also, the Minister for Finance will be empowered to approve other suitable forms of investment. Section 62B (1) of the Audit Act states:
Moneys standing to the credit of the Trust Fund-
We are talking only about trust funds-
may be invested by the Treasurer-
(a) in any securities of, or guaranteed by, the Government of the Commonwealth or of a State-
In other words, trustee authorised securities-
(b) on a deposit in a bank; or
(c) in the purchase of metal for coinage.

What we are really doing at the moment is allowing these trust fund managers to go out into the commercial world and to ignore the guaranteed investments as stipulated in section 82B of the Audit Act-in other words, the lower interest component area-so they can now invest money in the money market. I am a little concerned about this because these trust fund managers or the managers of organisations of the Commonwealth will tend to place an undue emphasis on the yield of the investment. We know traditionally that the yield of the investment which is contemplated will be very much lower than the yield on the trust fund investment account, so there will be the inevitability that managers will delay as long as possible making the original investment and secure as high a rate of interest as possible to maximise their income derived while these funds are on deposit. There will be a tendency to delay projects rather than to expedite them , to put the money which the Parliament or the authorities approve into the particular project as early as possible. Unfortunately, in many people's minds this will tend to be delayed because they will be trying to maximise the interest rate. The consequence, if we are not careful, could be an increased cost of the overall investment.

This is a matter of some concern because after all, these funds and traditional areas in which these moneys were invested have a lower rate of interest. If these trust funds are not invested in, where will they get their funds from? It is a demand and supply situation. They will have to go out into the market more and raise their interest rate, which means that the rates on Commonwealth bonds will be edged up because these moneys will no longer be available from traditional trust fund sources. Moneys from these sources amount to many millions of dollars each year. So we will find that the Government will have to edge up its rate of return on Commonwealth securities because the funds which have traditionally flowed from trust fund sources will now be diverted elsewhere into the commercial market. This can have many consequences because it will raise the yield and return on Commonwealth securities simply because of the demand and supply situation. I believe there will be a tendency on the part of project managers to delay certain projects because the yield on the investment will be lower than the yield on the temporary moneys invested for a particular time.

We all know that the moneys invested in Commonwealth securities are used for particular purposes. Therefore, the cost of servicing governments will tend to rise. At the end of the day, when all the arithmetic is done, I wonder whether we shall be any better off as a result of this. There is the other fact that there is the risk involved. Having authorised dealers in the money market increases the risk. It increases the flexibility, admittedly. But I just wonder whether, as a government, we should be directing these funds outside our own activities into the commercial area.

The other matter that I wish to raise concerns the changes to the Banking Act 1959. It has taken a long time to bring about these sorts of changes. I just wonder whether this Bill is the proper Bill to implement these sorts of changes. I remember speaking of concerns as long ago as the failure of the Bank of Adelaide. I said at that time that maybe that was the time to give a foreign bank an opportunity to come in in partnership with an Australian bank to test the waters and to provide this so-called extra capital from overseas. But no, the authorities at the time believed that it should be absorbed within the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group. But because of tremendous pressures from overseas banks, we are now giving serious consideration to opening up the Australian banking system to immense foreign competition, giving licences to banks from the United States, Japan, Britain and other centres.

What will this do to the Australian banking system? It will be forced out of those areas in which it is least profitable, reducing services to customers. I issue a warning that there are some international banks whose financial stability is very much at risk at present. I warn the Government that before it opens up the banking system, taking into consideration all of my other reservations, it should not allow some banks, and certainly some of those with big American names, to come into Australia unless we check their financial stability very carefully. We do not want Australia to be caught up in a world crash. Some of those banks are just so large that if they fail the ramifications around the world will be horrendous. They are bigger than many of the developed countries' economies. Their failure would cause ramifications. If they have major offices situated in Australia, Australian financial institutions and the Australian economy will suffer greatly as a result.

My final point concerns the change in the Public Accounts Committee Act. This is referred to on page 57. The proposal is to approve of the Public Accounts Committee forming sectional committees. We have to recognise that the PAC is the most active committee in the Parliament. Because of the number of references before it, it has seen fit to divide its activities into a number of sectional committees. For that reason, and in order to safeguard its workings, some changes have to be introduced to stipulate certain quorums. These are outlined on page 57 of the Bill. I believe that the breaking down of the Committee into sectional committees has enabled the PAC to continue its work in an efficient manner. I do not believe that the lessening of numbers has reduced the efficiency of the Committee. I commend its work to the Senate.

I commend the Bill, but with those minor reservations. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) has a knowledge of accounting. I also endorse Senator Evans's concern about company law matters being included in a Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill. I commend the Bill, with those reservations.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my custom to speak on the adjournment, Mr President, as you are well aware, but I rise on this occasion to respond to some comments made by Senator McLaren last week concerning the activities of the Tonkin Liberal Government in South Australia since it took office in 1979. I informed Senator McLaren that I would be speaking; unfortunately, he is not able to be present. However, this line of argument has been pursued by Senator McLaren over the three years since the Tonkin Government assumed office in South Australia. Last week, on 16 September, Senator McLaren stated, as reported at page 1025 of Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: We have a government in South Australia which was elected on a promise, among others, to stop the job rot and to get industry on its feet. Its claim at the time, that industry was lagging in South Australia under the then Labor Government, has been proved to be untrue by what has happened in the last three years.

I suggest that this claim cannot be supported by fact. Therefore, I regard it as an attempt to prop up the Australian Labor Party Opposition in South Australia. I want to record some of the facts concerning the performance of the Tonkin Government during its reign in South Australia. I do so under two headings: Firstly, investment and, secondly, employment. Since the election of the South Australian Liberal Government over $3 billion has been spent in that State by companies investing in projects or conducting feasibility studies. Those projects were identified in a publication that was produced earlier this year in South Australia under the heading 'Major Manufacturing Projects: Announced, Commenced or Completed since October 1979'.

Between October 1979 and June 1982 a total of 94 companies committed $1,705.9m to projects and another $1,336.5m was spent on feasibility studies. Some 88 firms invested in 117 projects and nine companies were carrying out 14 feasibility studies. Four companies are involved in both committed projects and feasibility studies. Of the 117 committed projects the majority involve investment of over $1m. I have a list which indicates that 22 projects are valued at between $100,000 and $500,000; 23 between $500,000 and $1m; 58 between $1m and $10m; 12 between $10m and $100m and two of $100m or over. The majority of feasibility studies also involve investment of over $1m. There is one study which involves investment of between $500 and $1m; five between $1m and $10m; five between $10m and $100m; and three of $100m or over. These successes are supported by facts. They compare more than favourably with the industries which either left South Australia or scaled down their operations during the period the Dunstan and Corcoran Labor governments were in office. One area that Dunstan did try to develop and attract investment to was the uranium enrichment industry . He was leading the field there-I pay him that compliment-until the left wing of the Labor Party disagreed with him. That stopped the initiative which was being displayed at that time in South Australia and which could have created jobs and attracted investment. I hope that those jobs and that investment will result but left wing influence spelled the end of Mr Dunstan as Premier of South Australia.

I now turn to the heading of employment. In this area South Australia has performed above average when compared with other States. Between August 1979 and July 1982 South Australia's work force increased by 6,200. In other words, the Tonkin Liberal Government had created 6,200 jobs. What happened under the previous Administration? Between August 1977 and August 1979, 20,000 jobs were lost to South Australia. The present Liberal Government has done all in its power to reverse the trend that was set in motion in those days. There are now more people employed in South Australia than there were three years ago. It is significant also that unemployment has grown at a lower rate in South Australia than in any other Australian State. Between August 1981 and August 1982 unemployment in South Australia increased by 4.1 per cent compared with the national average of 21.7 per cent. In other words, the State recorded an increase of less than one-fifth of the national average. Of course, the highest unemployment figures were recorded in New South Wales under a Labor Government.

I think the Tonkin Government has performed well in the face of a world-wide economic downturn and local stumbling blocks that have been put in its way. These local stumbling blocks include the Australian Labor Party and Australian Democrats members of the South Australian Legislative Council. These members voted to oppose the Roxby Downs project. In the words of Norm Foster, a former Labor councillor, they voted against employment. A recent independent survey has given an indication of the employment prospects of the Olympic Dam project. This study, which was conducted by research people at the Monash University, stated that some 13,800 jobs would result from this project and possibly this number could increase to 18,600. In spite of those reports and the prospects for South Australia the Opposition in the Legislative Council opposed that measure. I think that is a great pity.

In conclusion, the claims that have been made that the Tonkin Government has not stopped the job rot which was started by the Dunstan and Corcoran governments and that it has not succeeded in attracting industry, I believe, are totally false. These assertions are not supported by facts. The real problems faced by potential investors in South Australia and in job creation were caused by the Labor Party when in government. Under the Labor Party employment fell by 20,000 over two years and there was a flight of capital from South Australia. It is fitting to remind people of these facts in the few months leading up to the next State election.

In effect, each time a permanent resident leaves Australia, he requires a return endorsement to authorise uplift for return to Australia. Should he leave and return without a return endorsement, a number of enquiries may be made to establish his bona fides with a view to determining his status and entitlement to re-enter Australia (see answer to question 2040 (2)). Upon being granted re- entry a further A type entry permit may be stamped in his passport.
A return endorsement permits the holder to travel back to Australia within 3 years from date of last departure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

Shipments of skim milk powder consigned to HOMPI, Philippines arrived on and after 1st June through to 30th September 1976, on which the $25 per tonne commission is payable, should be debited against the ADI/ADC Corporation's share of the account currently held in Singapore.

Philippines
